Review_body: LeBron James worked hard to be the greatest and he's not about to let his son Dom be a slacker. Instead of basketball, Dom only wants to be a video game designer. WB's new computer algorithm Al G. Rhythm (Don Cheadle) wants to use LeBron's popularity to dominate the social media space. After LeBron rejects the offer, Al G. Rhythm kidnaps LeBron and Dom into the computer world. LeBron has to play a basketball game to win freedom for himself and his son. LeBron is sent to Tune World where he finds a lonely Bugs Bunny.LeBron is a functional actor and I like the older style Looney Tunes cartoon world. I love the Michael B. Jordan bit. I like some bits in this movie but it's way too long and too much of this is below par. The best part of this movie is Bugs Bunny in his Looney Tunes world and then they go off to various franchises to search for the rest of his friends. I like all of that. I like the animation style. Quite frankly, an animated LeBron James allows him off the hook for his acting. His voice is unique and works well for animation. Turning him in cartoon is a good thing. He doesn't have to act. He should stay a cartoon until he wins the game.His son Dom is a big problem. He's a brat. The excuse is that he gets enticed by Al G. Rhythm but it's a sorry excuse. At no point is he concerned about being in a computer simulation or about his father. The solution lies in Al turning Dom into a monster. When LeBron has his big emotional speech, Dom can slowly turn back into a boy looking to hug his father. That is much better characterization and progression in his story arc.Finally, this movie is hella busy and way too long. It is almost two hours long. The game is almost an hour long. They need to cut out at least fifteen minutes if not more. There is so much chaotic action that the long game section grows tiresome. People are excusing this for being a kids movie. Some of these references are going right over those kids' heads. They are not going to get A Clockwork Orange. For people who get all the references, this is bad for them. For kids who don't get the references, there's no point to it. This movie has fun bits. I love the Looney Tunes animation section. I don't like them digitized into computer animated. The plot is bad simplistic writing. The father son conflict could have been done better. This is way too long and that pushed me over the edge.

Live-action/animated comedies fall into two camps.For every Who Framed Roger Rabbit there is a Cool World.Space Jam: A New Legacy is a belated sequel to Space Jam which was released in 1996.The story line is LeBron James is a great basketball player but a dumb dad. He wants his son Dom to follow in his footsteps even though he is too short to be a basketball player.Dom wants to have fun and be a games designer. LeBron wants to just drill his sons to be the best like him, all work and no play.Al G Rhythm (Don West) is a rogue artificial intelligence program that abducts Dom leaving LeBron and the Warner Brothers cartoon characters playing an epic and upgraded basketball game.The story is for Bugs, Daffy and Co to come on the scene as LeBron tries to get a team together. He was hoping to get Superman and Batman. Instead it's Tweety, Taz and Foghorn Leghorn.It's an exercise on WB using its intellectual property to show Disney that it too has assets. So you have Harry Potter, Hanna Barbera cartoon characters, Justice League to Looney Tunes. Incongruously for a movie aimed at kids. It also has characters from Game of Thrones, It, The Devils and Clockwork Orange.It is frenetic and colourful. I found myself laughing a few times and I watched this movie with low expectations given the bad reviews this movie has had. The film is a little too long and the plot makes little sense. I wonder if LeBron James banned his kids from playing games consoles in real life!

Lebron James having a strong work ethic has trouble with his son who is not as into basketball as he wishes. They get sucked into a computer (Tron) by Don Cheadle playing a sinister algorithm. In order to get out and save his family James must win a basketball game with the Loony Tunes as his team mates.The story was bad. What I liked was the trip down memory lane with the tunes. Bugs Bunny doing William Shatner with all the pauses. Seeing famous villains in the background like Pennywise and the Wicked Witch of the West. In many ways this film is more for the adults who watch the film with their kids.Sorry I enjoyed it for the classic lines and if anything to hear the Notorious P. I. G. Rap. Who comes up with that? Great stuff.

Review title: Does this stink more than Pepe LePew?
Review_body: Now this or rather the original was not going to be cancelled because of one character. Whatever your feelings are about this character ... he is not included here - and if you actually check how his appearance would have gone down in the movie - you may change your perspective or your feelings about him not being included.But this "outrage" of some, who thought the character was deleted because of any backlash that might flush over the movie ... well it seems gone now. People are rather quite sad and mad about the overall outcome of the movie. And I would argue that LeBron is not really to blame for that. His acting abilities are better than those of MJ (and I say that as a big MJ fan).I think one of the biggest problems of the movie is how long it is. And how much "other stuff" it tries to push and pack into the movie. So many characters (and yet no Pepe - had to mention him once more for fun) and a 2 hour run time. As expected this looks way better than the original.And it tries to make more sense than the original too. While we had Aliens in the first one, this is closer to home. It also has Don Cheadle ... what a wonderful bad guy. But while it tries to make sense ... it falls flat on its face - no pun intended.The young ones might not mind and hopefully take the message this has (be yourself) and run with it - again no pun intended. The big ones may get a bit annoyed after a while I reckon. Still there are some good jokes in here (half time surprise guest/cameo), but also some really bad word puns/jokes - you may fall for them ... or not.The soundtrack overall is not as great as that of the original. There are some really good/updated/tweaked versions of some classics - like flavor in ya ear. So overall I have mixed feelings about this - I'm still a bit surprised this has such a low score right now (under 4 overall)

I watched the original live-action cartoon hybrid twice at the cinema when I was a kid, and many times after on video, it was always rumoured there would be a sequel, and it came twenty-five years later, directed by Malcolm D. Lee (Scary Movie 5, Girls Trip). Basically, basketball player LeBron James (as himself) wishes for both of his sons, Darius (Ceyair J. Wright) and Dom (Cedric Joe), to follow in his footsteps. But Dom, a child prodigy in computer software, instead dreams of becoming a video game developer. LeBron shows an interest in the arcade basketball game Dom has developed, but a glitch from a certain move causes his character to be deleted, which crushes Dom. Meanwhile, at Warner Bros. Studios, Burbank, state-of-the-art A. I., Al-G Rhythm (Don Cheadle) has secretly become self-aware and desires more recognition from the world. LeBron is invited to the studio to discuss a movie deal, taking Dom with him. While LeBron dismisses the idea, Dom shows an interest in the studio's software. Dom expresses his interest in software development, leading to a blow-up argument with his father at basketball camp when LeBron refuses to let him give up on the sport. Al-G lures the father and son to the studio basement and traps them in virtual reality. Insulted by LeBron's refusal to recognise his potential, Al-G takes Dom as his prisoner, and tells LeBron his son will only be released if the basketball star assembles a team together to beat him in a game of basketball. LeBron is then transported through the virtual space where he is dumped in Tune World. LeBron finds the animated world is deserted, with only cartoon character Bugs Bunny (Jeff Bergman) remaining. Bugs explains that Al-G persuaded the rest of the Looney Tunes to leave their world and explore other realities. Meanwhile, Al-G manipulates Dom to turn him against his father and helping him to develop and upgrade himself and his game, which he secretly intends to use against LeBron. Bugs wanting to help LeBron form his basketball team lures Marvin the Martian (Eric Bauza) to landing his spaceship in Tune World and he and LeBron steal the ship to travel to different worlds based on Warner Bros properties. In DC Comics, they find Daffy Duck (Bauza) and Porky Pig (Bauza) trying to be superheroes. In Mad Max: Fury Road, they find Road Runner and Wile E. Coyote. In Austin Powers, they find Elmer Fudd (Bauza) and Sylvester the Cat (Bergman), and Tweety Pie (Bob Bergen) when Sylvester spits him out. In Casablanca, they find Yosemite Sam (Bergman) playing "As Time Goes By". In Game of Thrones, they find Foghorn Leghorn (Bauza) riding a dragon. In The Matrix, they find Granny (Candi Milo) and Speedy Gonzales (Gabriel Iglesias). LeBron is unconvinced by the playing capabilities of the Looney Tunes; he insists they find a character with genuine talent. Finally, back in DC Comics, Lola Bunny (Zendaya) is with Wonder Woman (Rosario Dawson) to prove herself as an Amazonian, but Bugs convinces her to join the team to save LeBron's son. LeBron ignores the objections of Bugs and insists on coaching the "Tune Squad" on the fundamentals of basketball. When the time for the game arrives, the Tune Squad meet with Al-G's team, the Goon Squad, consisting of upgraded avatars of several active professional basketball players with superpowers and led by Dom. The Looney Tunes are surprised when they find themselves also upgraded, to become computer-animated beings, with more realistic features. To further the stakes, Al-G livestreams the game and abducts countless viewers, including LeBron's family, into the virtual reality while summoning all the Warner Bros. Characters to watch the game. Al-G announces that if the Tune Squad loses, all viewers will remain trapped in the "server-verse" for eternity and the Looney Tunes will be deleted permanently. With Dom Ball being a video game, LeBron and his team must contend with scoring high bonus points for style and execution, and the superpowers of the Goon Squad easily dominate the first half of the game. During the break, Sylvester attempts to recruit former Tune Squad member Michael Jordan, but finds actor Michael B. Jordan instead. LeBron realises that traditional basketball skills will not be enough and allows Bugs to devise the strategy for the second half using their cartoon physics to catch up with the Goon Squad. The Tunes manage to regain points until the teams are close to tying. LeBron confronts Dom and tells him he no longer wants to stand in the way of his dream. Dom forgives and trusts his father, and he abandons the Goon Squad. Al-G assumes control of the Goon Squad and uses his own abilities to make them seemingly unbeatable. Dom realises the only way to win the game is to use the glitch move, even though whoever does so will be deleted. During the final seconds of the game, Bugs sacrifices himself by performing the move, helping LeBron score the final point, winning the game and causing Al-G and the Goon Squad to be deleted. The James family and the abducted citizens are returned to the real world, while the Tunes gather around Bugs as he bids farewell before disappearing. In the real world, LeBron becomes closer to his family and supports Dom's decision to become a video game designer. After dropping Dom off at a video game trade event, LeBron is delighted when Bugs appears, he can't really "die", being a fictional character. He asks LeBron to put him up for a little while until he can find a way back to Tune World. Also starring Sonequa Martin-Green as Kamiyah James, LeBron's wife, Khris Davis as Malik, Harper Leigh Alexander as Xosha James, Xosha Roquemore as Shanice James, Stephen Kankole as Young LeBron, Gerald 'Slink' Johnson as Warner Bros. Security Guard (as Slink Johnson), Sarah Silverman as Warner Bros. Executive, Minari's Steven Yeun as Warner Bros. Executive, Ernie Johnson as Game Announcer, and Get Out's Lil Rel Howery as Game Announcer, with the voices of Jeff Bergman as Fred Flintstone and Yogi Bear, Fred Tatasciore as Taz the Tasmanian Devil, and Justin Roiland as Rick and Morty. Other Warner Bros. Movies and TV references and characters that can be spotted included: King Kong, The Wizard of Oz, The Flintstones, Yogi Bear, The Jetsons, What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?, Batman (1966), Wacky Races, Scooby Doo, Where Are You!, A Clockwork Orange, Captain Caveman and the Teen Angels, Superman (1978), The Shining, Gremlins, Thundercats, The Goonies, Batman (1989), Batman Returns, A League of Their Own, Batman: The Animated Series, Animaniacs, The Mask, Superman: The Animated Series, Mars Attacks!, Batman & Robin, Men in Black, The Iron Giant, Harry Potter and the Wizarding World, The Lord of the Rings, Ben 10, 300, The Conjuring, Dunkirk, It (Pennywise), Aquaman, and Joker (2019). James is likeable enough, Cheadle relishes being the villain, and of course Bugs Bunny and his cartoon friends are delightful. I was hoping for something entertaining, but it does not have quite the same charm as the original. The biggest problem is, it tries too hard to be clever, it is not all that funny, it tries too hard to imitate the wonder of Ready Player One cramming as many references as possible from Warner Bros. Properties, almost forgetting the Looney Tunes, and is much more style over substance. There is not a bad word to say about the animation, going from traditional hand-drawn to fantastic special CGI effects to make Bugs fluffy and so on, and any geek watching will have fun spotting the movie and TV characters. It is unfortunate that it is a bit of a let-down, but not a terrible part-animated fantasy sports comedy. Wacky Races was number 100, Captain Caveman and the Teen Angels was number 90, Yogi Bear was number 80, Foghorn Leghorn was number 61, Thundercats was number 54, Scooby-Doo, Where Are You! Was number 49, Road Runner was number 48, The Sylvester and Tweety Show was number 35, Daffy Duck was number 30, Looney Tunes / Merrie Melodies was number 20, The Iron Giant was number 12, The Flintstones was number 11, and Bugs Bunny was number 10 on The 100 Greatest Cartoons. Okay!

"Space Jam: A New Legacy" was not a movie that I was in any particularly rush to get to go and watch. But since my 11 year old son wanted to watch it, of course I found the time to go watch it with him.And while my son definitely enjoyed the movie, I must admit that I was not overly thrilled with this 2021 movie from director Malcolm D. Lee. "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is definitely a movie for the youngsters.Needless to say that this 2021 movie turned out to be as I had initially expected it would. And "Space Jam: A New Legacy" didn't really offer me much of any worthwhile entertainment or enjoyment.Visually then "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is definitely spot on, because the animation and art style used here is good and pleasing to the eyes. And there is no secret about the fact that it is the animated cartoon characters that carry the movie singlehandedly. It should be said that there are so many interesting characters and things going on in the background that "Space Jam: A New Legacy" could actually be watched twice; the first time for the movie alone, and the second time to take in all the background stuff. There are so many cameo from lots of different movies.Storywise then "Space Jam: A New Legacy" wasn't really impressive. And it certainly didn't manage to entertain me in a wholehearted manner. However, it is sort of impressive that six writers could collectively manage to come up with so little. The storyline told in "Space Jam: A New Legacy" just failed to captivate me and didn't offer much of any enjoyment or entertainment in comparison to the 1996 "Space Jam" movie - which was no masterpiece, but at least it fared better than the 2021 movie.As I mentioned above, then it is the animated cartoon characters that carry the movie, no doubt about it. But even with the likes of Don Cheadle and Sonequa Martin-Green on the cast list, there wasn't much to do. Then there was LeBron James instead of Michael Jordan; and boy that was just horrible to witness because he was fully stripped of anything even remotely to an acting talent."Space Jam: A New Legacy" is a movie for the youngsters, pure and simple, and aside from being nice visually, then there was nothing much to behold here.I am rating "Space Jam: A New Legacy" a less than mediocre four out of ten stars.

NBA Champ LeBron James goes on an epic adventure side by side with Bugs Bunny and a whole gang of undisciplined Looney Tune characters. It is a manic mashup of two worlds trying to show staid parents how to try and connect with their computer savvy kids. A basketball gem between LeBron and the cartoon characters against a heavy powered roster of pro ball players.Along with James appears, Jared Sullinger, Don Cheadle, Sonequa Martin-Green, Cedric Joe with announcer Ernie Johnson doing the play-by-play. Zendaya is the voice of Lola Bunny and Jeff Bergman voices Bugs Bunny and other cartoon characters.Is there a hidden agenda here to change attitudes and opinions of LeBron?

Review title: Proves That LeBron Is Not Jordan Even Off The Court
Review_body: After 25 years since Michael Jordan and the Looney Tunes appeared together in "Space Jam", another reboot or remake of the franchise was made in "Space Jam: A New Legacy". It stars LeBron James, who tries to chase Michael Jordan in the GOAT (Greatest Of All-Time) conversation, just proves once again that he is not him on and off the court especially with poor acting unlike Jordan,who was clearly having fun in his role in the original.It was apparent the comparisons will be made compared to the first movie released in 1996. While the digital and visual effects are a lot better, it proves once again that LeBron does not have the marketing appeal that Michael has. That is why you see a lot of ads(from LeBron and Warner Bros) implied on the film and focused on it rather on the story it has.Well, this movie was released to capitalize on both stars being the best of their respective generation's NBA players. Too bad that this movie proves once again that LeBron is not comparable to Michael even off the court.Take note,I am not even a Jordan fan. Wilt Chamberlain is the true G. O. A. T (Greatest Of All-Time) in NBA History. Hands down. Not LeBron nor Michael.

Warner Brothers have been itching to do a sequel to 'Space Jam' for years, perhaps even more so since the following Looney Tunes film ('Back in Action') didn't really capture the publics imagination in the same way.So here we go, 'Space Jam 2', that pits LeBron James now against cartoon bad guys in a Basketball game for reasons far too complicated to go into here.The first film wasn't great, but it had a charm about it. This one instead goes for all out tech trickery and shoving lots of Warner Brother's IP's down our throats in the hope that something sticks. The less said about the new version of Lola Bunny the better too.It's fine, it's enjoyable enough, but certainly not memorable.

Review title: Cutting room floor stuff that ought to have stayed there...
Review_body: This has to be in the running for turkey of the year. It's such a shameless example of bad storytelling, bad acting, and product placement that they might as well just have given you a goodie bag as you (prematurely) left the cinema replete with your Warner Brothers tattoo. It's centres around the son of LeBron James being kidnapped by an evil AI. The only way he can be rescued is by LBJ and his new bestie "Bugs Bunny" putting together a team that can win a basketball game against team selected by the AI. That's about the height of it - there are no characterisations worthy of note amongst the humans, and though it is quite nice to see some of Warner's cartoon characters on a big screen again, any nostalgia that evokes is soon washed away by the sheer naffness of this whole enterprise. Quite whom this is for is anyone's guess - but it sure wasn't for me...

Space Jam: A New LegacyBasketball wiz LeBron James is having problems with son Dom, who is more interested in computer games than basketball. On a trip to Warner Brothers, computerised mastermind Al G Rhythm sucks them all into the WB server to play Dom's computer game version of basketball.If you saw the original Space Jam then there are no huge surprises here. Let me start by saying that the animation - both traditional hand-drawn and CGI - is terrific, as is the integration with live and CGI backgrounds.LeBron James can't act and doesn't come across well as the fictional version of himself. It takes forever for the story to get going - I had a couple of small boys in front of me, hyper with excitement, and Mum took them out after half an hour because the film simply hadn't captured their attention at that point.I didn't dislike the film, but it did a Ready Player One with characters from various WB franchises and, during important sequences, I was concentrating on spotting characters in the audience for the game rather than concentrating on plot.

Like really? So much advertisement and commercial put about this film, how's going to be great, even the name " A new Legacy" and everything for this? Really disappoited. It didn't bring anything new, whole concept looked really poor and average, the only part which was kind of nice that they've put whole DC Movies personages here, I liked this idea. But everything else, despite this, was hideous. If they didn't have idea how to create second part maybe it wasn't necessary? One of the worst movie of 2021 so far.

This may be the most patronizing, soulless corporate hackery passed off as a movie instead of the near-two-hours commercial that it is for WarnerMedia IPs and its product-placement partners I've ever seen, and I've seen the first "Space Jam" (1996), as well as Steven Spielberg's "Ready Player One" (2018) that this sequel crassly rips-off. I was under the impression that I subscribed to HBO Max for new movies--not for advertisements to subscribe to the streaming channel I'm already subscribed to. At least, the original "Space Jam" made some sense; it was about basketballer Michael Jordan playing basketball to win his right to be paid for his brand against a slave-capturing amusement park, Moron Mountain... I said it only made some sense. In the pretentiously-titled sequel threatening a franchise, "A New Legacy," basketballer LeBron James plays a video game to win his right not to be digitized and turned into an obnoxious movie brand, but that's exactly what the real King James did in agreeing to do this obnoxious, digitized branding movie. Oxymoron Mountain.Besides Warners pretending to be against the very thing the fictional Warners is doing in its movie and what the real company did in making it--i.e. A faux indictment against what movie culture has become as brought to you by one of the biggest multinational conglomerates behind said culture--and James playing a character with more apparent character than his brand really has, we get the stupidest of father-son relationship dilemmas. Stop wasting time creating a game, son, and concentrate on playing this other game instead, and stop having fun, 'cause I'm the grumpy old man of throwing a ball through a hoop. All of it would be more tolerable, too, if the Looney Tunes were allowed to remain traditionally-animated cartoons instead of computer animations that are, then, turned into even-uglier computer animations. Or if weren't so cloying. Or overly hyperactive even for Looney Tunes. Cartoon basketball was bad enough, but overwrought video-game cartoon basketball as observed by every IP in WarnerMedia's vault--and that move as convincingly as the generic fans in an NBA 2K video game--manages to be so much worse.Even if a joke here or there is almost funny, it doesn't matter. (The best may be the Michael Jordan cameo, which I saw coming, but still wasn't bad. Most of them, though, involve more branding, such as cartoon James's fall creating a hole in Looney Tunes land the shape of the Nike swoosh logo, or his attempts to recruit DC superheroes, which are also owned by Warner.) That's because the entire thing is so ugly, hackneyed and ultimately insulting to the intelligence of the viewer-customer that it cannot be redeemed. A movie must have some underlying value--it needs a soul, to be forgiven. This one doesn't.

Well, good thinking on WB Studio using only in-house supporting characters (Bugs, Daffy, Elmer, Road, Sylvester, etc.) - saves a lot of money.Not sure that I like the message of "Be the best basketball player ... focus on the game of basketball & not (tech) distractions." The problem is that the odds of making a life long living from bball is statistically very much lower than being tech comfortable (e.g. Programming; repair; innovation; application). And, likely to be less serving/helping to humanity & the Earth.

Review title: Dog water with some average entertainment
Review_body: I understand the hate Labron James can't act he should stick to basketball; even Micheal Jordan did better in the original without much acting! One of very few aspects I enjoyed was the references to other movies and the toons did great. I yawned even though I got plenty of sleep although glad I saw in theater. I rarely not enjoy movies but this adaptation was pretty bad even in the original the young version of Micheal played basketball really well.

Review title: i was forced to watch this
Review_body: All I'll say is I told you so...Last Words: It's complete hash.

I'm amazed at how so much happens in this film and yet nothing really happens at all. There's a decent if pointed set-up where LeBron James wants his son to pursue basketball but his real talents lie in video game development. The execution of this story is a strangely contrived adventure where the antagonist traps both LeBron and his son in a virtual world for very thinly defined reasons. That's the main problem of this film - the character motivations and plot conflicts seem very thin, as if the screenplay were unfinished. For example, the backstory of the Looney Tunes characters leaving their world for other movie worlds was badly explained and I was still wondering why they were scattered and why they decided to come back. The skits on the other movie worlds were neat individually, but they didn't add up to much. The thin plotting and aimless animated sketches are a flaw shared by this film's predecessor, despite what the nostalgists may claim, but this time it's too chaotic to be fun and the plot was muddled up.

"Space Jam: A New Legacy" is an Animation - Comedy movie in which we watch a new version of "Space Jam" of 1996. Instead of Michael Jordan there is LeBron James who has to work together with Bugs Bunny and the Looney Tunes to win a basketball match and not letting artificial intelligence achieve its goal.Since I had already watched the first movie of "Space Jam" I knew what to expect from this new version of it. The direction which was made by Malcolm D. Lee was average without achieving to intrigued audience and make them feel that they are also a part of this movie following his main characters. The interpretations of LeBron James who played as himself, Don Cheadle who played as Al G. Rhythm and Cedric Joe who played as Dom James were good and their combination worked pretty good. To sum up, I have to say that "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is an average comedy movie and I advise you to lower your standards if you want to watch it otherwise you will be disappointed.

Review title: Colorful, fun, and a bit hallow as a movie.
Review_body: 3 out of 5 stars.I loved the first Space Jam film which took Michael Jordan into a looney toon world to play ball. This film modernizes with the digital world of warner bros studios. Taking Lebron James into the digital world. Where he meets looney toons. And in order to get his son back. Which they had a conflict which Lebron always wanted his son to play ball but he is obsessed with making video games. Lebron James would have to form a team to play ball against a digitalized characters that would break the rules against basketball.Decent story about father and son. And a theme about doing what makes you happy. Lebron James is a fun addition. The visual effects and animations is great. Especially when it digitizes the toon characters. It is colorful. Fun. And it has a lot of cameos of warner bros characters.Acting was okay. Don Cheadle playing a villain was eh. The direction does get forgettable. And feels hallow when it comes to anything else. Like it feels like a one time view kind of movie. Until your bored with the humor.

Review title: Captures None Of The Fun Or Magic Of The Original
Review_body: In 1996, the original Space Jam "had something", so to speak. Seeing Michael Jordan on the big screen interacting with the Looney Tunes was a first-of-its-kind sort of experience, and despite the ridiculous concept it worked perfectly. Sadly, this long-await sequel captures absolutely none of that magic or fun.For a very basic overview, Space Jam: A New Legacy sees Warner Brother's sentient artificial intelligence Al G. Rhythm (Don Cheadle) hatch a plan inside the "server-verse" to finally get the recognition he feels he deserves. Central to that mission? Abducting LeBron James and family to play in a high-stakes basketball game that pits father against son. Along the way, James must root out the old Looney gang for the epic court contest.I will readily admit that nostalgia for the original got me into the theater to see this sequel. Absolutely no doubt about that. However, I will not concede that the same nostalgia is preventing me from giving this one a better rating than 3/10. "A New Legacy" is just a bad movie, plain and simple, for numerous reasons...-Whereas Michael Jordan just had to show up and be himself in the original, here LeBron James is given the emotional heavy-lifting tasks. Predictably, it does not go well. He cannot believably convey a single emotion.-A lot of people are criticizing the decision to showcase so many WB properties (Harry Potter, Superman, Batman, Matrix, Game of Thrones, etc.) in this film. That didn't so much bother me, and I actually enjoyed the concept of a tongue-in-cheek poking fun at those topics. But it all comes crashing down when the finished product looks suspiciously like an algorithm-created property that the plot was trying to skewer!-The "Looney Tunes playing basketball" concept is no longer new (by virtue of the '96 effort), and nothing is done to spruce that avenue up whatsoever. Same old gags just replayed again. Also, the way we interact with athletes is so different now that James simply cannot command the cultural cache that MJ once did. Just having him physically present isn't enough like it may have been in the mid-90s.Overall, "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is a clunker, no two ways around it. It isn't the worst film I've ever seen (it got me to chuckle a few times), but it is almost completely devoid of any real emotion or fun, in stark contrast to its predecessor that is still considered one of the most fun films ever made.

Review title: Obsession with pop-culture overrides everything else in this forgettable adventure
Review_body: There wouldn't be many proclaiming from the rooftops that 1996's Michael Jordan/Loony Tunes starring Space Jam is a cinematic masterpiece, but there was an undeniable and energetic charm to that real life/animated hybrid that ensured it became not only a box office hit, but a beloved childhood favourite for many children of the 90's.Operating at the peak of his world dominating powers, Jordan made for a fun leading man in the chaotic toon filled basketball filled escapade and established his legacy as a once in a lifetime athlete and pop culture phenomenon but wanting to prove his metal as a claim to the throne of the true GOAT of the NBA world, Lakers superstar LeBron James spearheads this modern day take on the Space Jam brand with A New Legacy, a likely box office beast that sadly lacks any of the charm or spark of the original, as you can't help but feel as though Malcolm D. Lee's film is nothing but a James love-fest moulded in with a dream Warner Brothers marketing department idea that is going to make some serious money for the company over the coming months/years.To be fair, A New Legacy isn't a complete write-off, upon initially hearing about another Space Jam taking shape under the guidance of James and Black Panther director Ryan Coogler's hand as a producer, one would've been sane enough thinking things could only turn out very badly for all involved but Lee's film isn't bereft of decent ideas and fun moments that come and go through its close to two hour run-time and there's a nostalgic joy getting to once more see the Loony Tunes gang get a moment in the spotlight but thanks to James's atrocious acting skills, a big collection of flat jokes and an incessant push from the film to cram in as pop culture references as it can allow, A New Legacy is more often than not a chore to sit through and one that potentially will bore its young audience rather than capture the imaginations of them.Seemingly taking inspiration from Ready Player One's rulebook, once James gets sucked into a computer-verse run by Don Cheadle's delusional A. I Al G. Rhythm and forced to compete in a world changing Basketball match against his own son whilst reuniting a disbanded group of Loony Tunes members, there's an obsession with A New Legacy to throw everything at as from a cameo point of view with everyone from the Joker, Mad Max and Harry Potter getting a run (or strangely enough for a kids film Austin Powers or A Clockwork Orange) and when the film resorts to scenes such as Porky Pig in a rap battle or James and Bugs Bunny going into the Matrix you really do start to wonder what the film is trying to do or who its trying to do it for?Thankfully for us and for James's reputation he ends up spending half of the film in animated form, saving us from more high school level of acting talents that would've further dampened A New Legacy's struggle to find itself and stand on its own two legs, as it ends up feeling like nothing more than a reminder to us all that James is the greatest athlete on the planet (did you know?) and that you should probably buy some his or Warner Brothers merchandise if you haven't already.Final Say -Saved by a few imaginative scenes and a welcome return from the Loony Tunes gang, Space Jam: A New Legacy suffers badly from Jame's poor screen presence/acting ability and an inability to find its own identity amongst its endless procession of nods and winks to other properties and brand names.2 cases of mistaken identity out of 5.

Review title: Ci tiu filmo estas tuta acajo
Review_body: I watched the movie the first time and thought it was poorly written. I didn't care for the disjointed storyline, the logic of the script, the idea behind Warner Bros having a super computer with AI that could do anything like scanning a person and teleporting them in to digital format (TRON?)I watched the movie a second time to give it a second chance but it was still poorly written, but even more of the flaws came out. I realized it was one giant advertising scheme for Warner Bros. They pushed their entire catalog. (Ready Player One?)I watched it a third time, this round I had my family with me. No one could stay interested. The writing was still terrible. The plot was ridiculous and lacked continuity. The plot sucked. The movie was like one giant commercial. LeBron was terrible. This was basically one giant reboot of the original movie with some minor changes.It was so bad the third time that everyone decided to put their faces in to YouTube, Pinterest or Facebook. No one was interested, even the kids. We ended up turning it off.I don't dislike (I didn't care for the Cleveland to Miami act) LeBron but the guy can't act. He's a ball player, like he said, and movies aren't his thing. Michael Jordan was better. He was believable. LeBron is like a lifeless, dull, sap. He couldn't convey emotion if you pumped four million volts through him.I liked the cartoon bit, but when they converted to CG, that was a downer. I didn't care for it.The movie also lacked a good soundtrack. I guess it is a timing issue. The original Space Jam had some amazing tunes at that period. Fly Like An Eagle, The Winner, Space Jam, I Believe I Can Fly. None of the tunes from this movie will beat I Believe I Can Fly.Yeah, I dislike this movie, but not Lebron. I didn't care for LeBron's ego. This movie was all Lebron's ego. The guy thinks he is Jordan, but he isn't. Stop trying to copy Jordan. Go do something original.

Space Jam: A New Legacy (alternatively Space Jam 2) is a 2021 fantasy comedy sequel starring Lebron James,Don Cheadle and Zedaya as the new voice for Lola. Lebron James plays himself who's son Dom is a whizz at creating video games. However when Lebron and his son visit the Warner Bros world they are both sucked into the Warner Bros software by an A. I named Ali G(Cheadle), Lebron must team up with the Looney Tunes to get his son back before its too late.There is alot of hidden references from this film from past and present Warner Bros films from Wonder Woman to Batman to even the likes of Iron Giant,The Flintstones and of course The Mask. As well as this we have hidden worlds from Game Of Thrones to Harry Potter to Gotham City. It was nice too seeing hand drawn animation too as well as CGI animation.If you love Ralph Breaks The Internet and Ready Player One than you will love this film.There's a hidden cameo from Sarah Silverman and Micheal B Jordan as well as Mike Myers as Austin Powers.

Review title: If doing this movie prevented LeBron from going all the way to the finals...
Review_body: The movie was not that bad at all, really. I actually enjoyed it for what it was and my judgement of it will always be tainted because LeBron don't play for my team.If you love LeBron you will love this move because it's all about him. It only truly sucks because while Michael Jordan can't act either, your royal Airness at least understood that.Otherwise the animation was actually really good , the movie had a lot of funny moments and it was a pretty decent tear jerker.I loved the fact that the movie paid homage to everything that Warner Bros. Has to offer. It's not a bad list of stuff even though they concentrated far too much on Batman.My hopes were not high but I like what I saw overall.

Review title: If you want just a fun time, then Space Jam: A New Legacy is that film for you.
Review_body: I took my nephew to see this, and we both found it entertaining. You go into a film like this not expecting anything deep, but just a fun time and too forget about your problems, and if you didn't like it, your entitled not to.Almost similar to the first film that came out in 1996, Lebron James basic playing himself, has to save his son from an evil computer entity(Don Cheadle), who challenges him to a game of basketball, so Lebron puts together a team basically the looney toons characters.A fun movie, go in expecting nothing more of less.

I saw "Space Jam:A New Legacy", starring LeBron James-Trainwreck, Entourage_tv; Don Cheadle-the Avengers movies, House of Lies_tv; Cedric Joe-Loving Him, Modern Family_tv and Sonequa Martin_Green-Star Trek:Discovery_tv, The Walking Dead_tv.This is a sequel to the original 1996 sports/cartoon collaboration-this one takes place in cyber space instead of outer space-and it still features a combination of live action and animation. LeBron is the sports figure here-Michael Jordan was in the original-that gets roped into the cyber world of an artificial intelligence bad guy played by Don. Cedric plays LeBron's son, who gets kidnapped by Don to force LeBron to play a game of basketball in the serververse-kind of like in the Matrix. LeBron's wife is played by Sonequa. LeBron enlists the Looney Toons characters-Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, etc,-to help him win and try to rescue his son. The effects are good and there are lots of cameos-mostly in the crowd scenes-to keep an eye out for, both real and animated. The cameos range from sports figures to Warner Bros. Properties and even other sources. I remember seeing King Kong, Batman & Robin, It, Game of Throne characters, Harry Potter characters, The Wizard of Oz characters....well, you get the drift. During the end credits, there are photos of the toons and real people-such as Porky Pig fighting Ronda Rousey-but nothing at the very end, except the signature line is heard, 'That's All, Folks!'.It's rated "PG" for cartoon violence and language and has a running time of 1 hour & 55 minutes.If you have little ones, it would be a good one for the family. I don't think I would buy it on DVD but it would be alright, as a rental.

Review title: When you stop and think about it, jam is . . .
Review_body: . . . pretty disgusting. No one wants to get into a big jam. No one asks for second helpings of toe jam. Your morning commute never goes well when your toast is spread with traffic jam. So there is little surprise that SPACE JAM: A NEW LEGACY could just as easily be titled SPICE JAM: STEWED LEPROSY. As the latter heading suggests, SPACE JAM trashes everything that it touches, from CASABLANCA and KING KONG to Bugs, Daffy and Yosemite Sam. If NASA had launched a golden DVD of SPACE JAM 2 on Voyager One, it's highly probable that some less tolerant alien civilization would have destroyed Planet Earth by now for its apparent lack of intelligent life. Just don't blame Marvin the Martian for getting us into such a jam.
5/10 - I'm one of the few that actually enjoyed the cross-over of all the Warner Brothers properties, but all in all, this movie is not memorable enough to warrant a rewatch.

Review title: People who complain about this film forget the first Space Jam wasn't good either.
Review_body: Space Jam: A New Legacy (2021) is a movie we recently saw in theatres two days ago. The storyline follows LeBron James who wants his son to be a basketball player while his son is more interested in designing and building video games. When WB approaches LeBron about a new campaign, which was designed by their own Artificial Intelligence (AI), LeBron hates the idea and turns it down, upsetting the AI. The AI decides to kidnap his son and only allows him to return home if Bron can beat the AI at a game of basketball. Bron will be given his team of toons to work with while the AI forms his own goon squad. This movie is directed by Malcolm D. Lee (The Best Man) and stars LeBron James, Don Cheadle (Crash), Sarah Silverman (School of Rock), Steven Yeun (Walking Dead) and Lil Rel Howery (Get Out). The storyline for the holistic movie is nothing special, but the toon characters are awesome and their introductions into the film was magnificent (the best segments of either film are in this picture - the Matrix and Mad Max sequences are legendary). I loved the background characters at the game and loved how Disney showed they do more than cartoons and super heroes (The Nun, It, Gremlins, etc). The animation for this film was excellent and superior to the first film (as you'd expect). Overall, this was a lot of fun for the family and a hair below the original. People who complain about this film forget the first Space Jam wasn't good either. I'd score this a 5/10 and recommend taking your kids to see it.

When I was younger I used to watch the Looney Tunes and I loved and the original Space Jam is a guilty pleasure film for me so I had a tiny bit of excitement for the sequel New Legacy and I had the chance to watch it today and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees Lebron James sucked into an artificial world where he must unite the Toon Squad to win a game of Basketball.Main Character
As mentioned above, Lebron James plays himself as the lead character and he seems like a pretty charismatic guy in real life but that is not the case here. He is so boring to watch here, and for the majority of the film he is just reacting to what is going on with the whole world. The film forces him to deliver some emotional scenes and he just can't do it and it really makes the film fall flat.Supporting Characters
Don Cheadle plays the bad guy in the film and he just looks like he is having a really fun time with the role, this is no great villain performance but he is possibly the most entertaining part of the film and that has to count for something. Onto the toons and they are pretty entertaining, the old classics are there by Buggs Bunny, Wile Coyote and Foghorn Leghorn and memories of my childhood came back. But they also get put into the background for Lebron, I never really got Zendaya voicing Lola Bunny and guys like Semmity Sam and Daffy Duck have little to do and the biggest negative is giving my favourite character Marvin Martian barely anything to do. I didn't really care for Lebron's onscreen son and Sonequa Martin-Green is really wasted as Lebron's wife.Story
The story offers very little. The whole theme of fatherhood is let down by weak performances and a weak dramatic script. The first film had the looney tunes in the forefront but here they feel like afterthoughts, in favour for Warner Bros very clear poor marketing and they try to cram all these franchises that they own in order to try and convince you to watch them. This is despite the demographic of young kids will have no idea what half of these franchises even are.Script
The script does have a few chuckle worthy moments and although I complained about the obvious marketing ploy, a lot of the cameos were quite funny to me as a big film fan. But the drama really isn't there and a good chunk of the comedy feels like it should have been left in the prime days of the tunes.Style
The animation for this film is pretty great, it looks exactly like it should for the majority, until it goes to more CGI instead of animation and it becomes a bit strange. Also this film felt really long, the last basketball game itself feels like an hour long and I shouldn't be feeling like that in a family friendly film with Looney Tunes characters.Overall
Overall, Space Jam: New Legacy is a bad film. It will have some people who grew up with The Looney Tunes and the original film but they will not like it and kids shouldn't be bought up watching this garbage of a film cause it has some nice visuals.

Review title: Don't know why so many haters, because this film full of insane funny, and basketball battle scene! Really should watch it!
Review_body: This film start with a mother talking with her son "LeBron", and LeBron playing his basketball game scene! As turnout, this film about LeBron, and his son "Dom" need to team up with Tunes team, to defeat the Goons team, and eventually prevent human trap in the Warner Bros. Serververse forever! Entire film full of Looney Tunes' character funny scene, and funny basketball battle scene! Make the film quite watchable! At the end, after defeat the Goons team, and save the human, Bugs Bunny back to the human world with LeBron! That's it! A quite entertain film!

Review title: Michael Jordan was a WAY better basketball player AND and actor, not even CLOSE!!! THIS IS TERRIBLE!!!!
Review_body: Lebron cant act I mean its embarrassing to watch, Michael Jordan wasnt a great actor either but he had charisma and a presence and he was the ultimate showman in pretty much everything he did. The NBA doesnt have an MJ, or a Doctor J, Karl malone. They were great at basketball AND great showman!! Or and MAGIC!!!! Do yourself a BIG favor skip this cash grab garbage and go watch the original. 25 years for this????? We still have pixar and DreamWorks!!! Warner brothers is making some seriously BAD decisions might be to little to late!!

Review title: COME FOR THE COLORS...LEAVE FOR THE STORY...!
Review_body: The recent reboot/sequel/whatever to the 1996 original now stars LeBron James, playing himself, out to match B-ball skills w/the Looney Toons gang versus Don Cheadle's sinister IA whose handpicked & enhanced goon squad led by LeBron's bitter son. What leads up to this disagreement is LeBron's insistence that his boy attend a basketball camp (while the tyke wants to go to some E3 gamer conference) as they're summoned to the Warner Bros. Studios lot to hear a pitch developed by Cheadle's algorithm. Dismissing the idea as absurd, Cheadle decides to take advantage of the son's already obvious friction w/his pere to lure him into his world (sort of a matrix vision of the computer's NeuroNet). LeBron follows suit but needs to reunite the toons (already disbanded by Cheadle's program to points unknown) so he recruits Bugs Bunny to collect his cohorts for the final game which is populated by many a Warner Bros. Property (King Kong, The Iron Giant, The Herculoids, Space Ghost, et al) but also humans who will forfeit their lives if LB's team loses. Not really my cup of tea (it wasn't my cup of tea back in 1996 & I didn't come out for the Brendan Fraser/Jenna Elfman starrer Looney Toons: Back in Action either) but just as a matter of being that guy who needs to see what the fuss is all about, it's a box I just checked off but bottom line the final product isn't offensive or nausea inducing but as a product of studio synergy, it gets the job done & people plugged into the material (whether because of nostalgia for the first film) will find the same happy place here for them to prop up their feet & let their eyeballs absorb the colors.

Review title: Space Jam 2: Welcome to the Slam
Review_body: Lebron can't act. Look, MJ wasn't gonna win any awards for the original Space Jam but at least he was giving it a shot. Lebron in this is just a hunk of wood with a beard drawn on, he brings nothing to it. They call him King way to much for it to feel natural. The story makes no sense and doesn't even follow it's own premise all that well. The turn the tunes into 3D characters which feels like a mistake. The color tone is way too dark and ominous for a Space Jam movie. Don Cheadle's character makes no sense at all. The ending is ridiculous and the scene at the very end just made me angry.

Review title: I wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt, but ultimately its exactly what you would expect
Review_body: A somewhat fine film overrun with commercialism and forced antics in an attempt to remain relevant- Space Jam A New Legacy could have easily been something special, but instead- its just rather lazy. Lebron James steps in to take over the basketball all-star role this time around, and he's honestly pretty corny, but fine all in all. James 'character' in the film is just so thinly written to make way for the film story, ultimately weighing down what could have been another fun adventure with a different star. James is hardly the films biggest problem though, and out of all of it, I oddly have to name Don Cheadle as the worst thing about this film. Not only is his character a poorly written and constructed device (that's also kinda a perfect metaphor for Warner Bros oddly) but his over the top performance and wooden delivery make for honestly one of the worst villains i've ever seen on screen. The film is thankfully entertaining, although it can be kinda cringeworthy to watch at times. They try really hard to appeal to the kids of this generation, and it is so incredibly forced that it can honestly be quite hard to watch. I enjoyed seeing all my favorite tunes again, but the CGI overkill in the second half of the film is a bit too much to bare- and honestly just feels like one huge commercial. Yes, there are commercial elements in the films first half, but I felt like it still had some heart and tue humor to it- it wasn't trying too hard or shoving products in our face. In the end, the film had a few funny moments, and didn't bore me (as some may say it did) but it's far too shallow to be a decent film- and far too forced to gain any sympathy.My Rating: 4.4/10.

Review title: Space Jam for a New Generation 21st Century
Review_body: Lebron James replaces original star Michael Jordan that is now 25 years old this year 2021. Jordan was like retired briefly when the movie comes out mixing life imitating art there.Lebron is still playing in the NBA with trying to get through to his video game soon to be creator preteen son Dom. But Dom wants to be Dom and Lebron wants Dom to be like his own father. But when Don Cheadle plays a rogue AI that turns into life, he tries to turn son against father.And that when both get sucked into the video game AI there, Don tries to use his son and "befriend" Dom. While Lebron finally realizes why his "son" loves video games through the help of Bugs Bunny who has lost his friends over them being manipulated over AI as well.As he manages to get them back and you will see how, he and LeBron in trying to get Lebron back to the real world and back to his son. If they end up winning the game AI forces them to play with the Goon squad.By playing against the Goons over NBA and WNBA players that AI created in the players playing themselves. If Bugs and Lebron loses, then they will be forever in the AI world. If the two and the team win then they will return home.The movie may not ever live up to the original but it is all good fun and pop culture references! Cute film. Won't win any awards but good for the family.

Space Jam: A New Legacy isn't good, it takes a little too long to get going, it's over reliant on brands and IP which is very distracting in final battle, especially as they look so cheap and most of the jokes aren't funny. However, it's still fun with lots of hilariously bad moments throughout. LeBron James gives a good lead performance and Don Cheadle is really fun to watch in an extremely unhinged performance. Most of the CG is impressive and it's relatively well paced.

Review title: Clever writing - comedic and zany at times; wholesome and realistic at others
Review_body: Space Jam: A New Legacy, the cartoon sequel, brings the whole Looney Tunes gang back to the court, only this time with the reigning king of basketball, Lebron James. This comedy combines live action with animation and is filled with life lessons, funny catch phrases, loads of glitzy digital effects and a glimpse of Warner Bros. Cinematic library.When LeBron James and his son, Dom (Cedric Joe) get mysteriously sucked into the Warner Bros. Digital world by a rogue AI supervillain (Don Cheadle), nonsense and chaos ensue. Dom is kidnapped and LeBron is challenged to a high-stakes basketball game by the evil AI. Lebron must form the most winning team to get his son back and, a loss could leave him and all those he loves, stuck in the server-verse forever. Lebron and his Looney Tunes pal Bugs Bunny meet up for a wild adventure through the server-verse. Will he win, or be trapped there forever? Watch to find out.The writing is clever. It is comedic and zany at some points; at others, it is very wholesome and realistic. The animation is outstanding! The movie combines traditional animation with three-dimensional computer graphics and live action. LeBron's cartoon character is spot on. The tour through the server-verse is so enjoyable. Seeing iconic characters like Yogi Bear, Pennywise, Iron Giant and King Kong is every movie junkie's dream! Eric Bauza plays a very important role in this movie as he voices Daffy Duck, Foghorn Leghorn, Elmer Fudd, Marvin the Martian and Porky Pig. Jeff Bergman is also instrumental in this film as he voices Bugs Bunny, Sylvester and Yosemite Sam. Both Eric and Jeff voice their characters so well that it's like listening to the original cartoons! Space Jam: New Legacy also features Don Cheadle, who is the rogue AI AL. G. Rhythm. His villainous role features a wide range of emotion and I give him two thumbs up for his outstanding performance. My favorite character is Granny because she is a good-natured, protective, spunky old woman that has some epic moves.The messages of this movie are that family is everything and there is power in chasing your dreams. Sometimes, we need some loony things in our life to make it better. There is mild language and a lot of action.I give Space Jam: A New Legacy 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 7 to 18, plus adults. It's a great family movie. Fans of the original will love this, too. This movie releases July 16, 2021 in theaters and on HBO Max.Reviewed by Katherine S., KIDS FIRST!

Having not seen the first Space Jam & vaguely remembering it, I went to see this after seeing a couple of trailers. The film wasn't bad.The film follows Superstar LeBron James and his young son, Dom! The 2 get trapped in digital space by a rogue AI. In order to get home in one piece, LeBron teams up with Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and the rest of the Looney Tunes gang for a high-stakes basketball game against the AI's digitised champions of the court, a powered-up roster called the Goon Squad!I found the film to good, not amazing, but good! It isn't nearly as good as Looney Tunes Back In Action which by the way I haven't seen in years, but remember as being a great film & similar in the Live Action Animation cross over! The laughs were alright as with the jokes & innuendos!The film did however, drag! The pacing wasn't great & the film overly long at 1hr & 48mins! It could've been 25-30mins shorter! For a Kids/Family Film, it's too long!Overall, it's not a bad film, but it could have been better & shorter!5/10.

LeBron James wants his son Domto follow his footsteps into basketball. Dom however has more of a passion for creating video games. One day an A. I. programme called Al G. Rhythm kidnaps Dom into what he calls the serververse; and the only way LeBron can save his son (along with thousands of other people/characters) is to play a game of basketball. Not any game of basketball though. The upgraded version created by his own son. To add to the craziness LeBron is forced to team up with the looney tunes to take on Dom himself alongside upgraded versions of professional basketball stars.Audiences who are fans and familiar with the various Warner Brothers intellectual properties would be delighted to see many of the characters they have watched before get a cameo in this film. There are literally too many of them to mention. There are definitely funny parts in the movie. The Looney Tunes cast certainly were one of those who delivered the comedic parts. Don Cheadle also had many comic parts as well. He actually fit in the role of a comedic villain. His character sucked, but you could at least see Cheadle was having fun making the film. From hybrid animation to computer graphics. The transformation of the Looney Tunes cast into 3D CGI was done well. The story was definitely supposed to be a hit. But what made it uninteresting was a combination of uneven pacing and rushed editing. The film ran for about two hours and yet it seemed like a rush of clips tied together to form the film. There were scenes that jumped from one point to the next without any context whatsoever. The film also seemed to serve as one long commercial showcase the various intellectual properties of Warner Brothers. It was great to see many of them on the same screen, but their cameos were a little off considering they were just there.Overall, Space Jam: A New Legacy might definitely please younger audiences because of its visuals and bright colors. But the story and the theme seemed to be buried underneath a seemingly infinite cameos that may distract the audiences.

Review title: As a 90's Kid, I Thoroughly Enjoyed This Movie!!!
Review_body: I was 6 years old when the original Space Jam came out. It's always been one of my childhood favorites. I never imagined that after 25 years, they'd actually make a sequel to it, and now that it's here; it really isn't all that bad. No way will it ever be as nostalgic as the original, but if you're a fan of the original, and love cinema, especially films and television shows made by Warner Bros. Then you're in for quite a surprise. There are many nods, pop culture references and Easter eggs to great franchises such as Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, Mad Max, The Matrix, Casablanca, The Wizard of Oz, King Kong, The Iron Giant, Rick and Morty, the DC Universe and much more.LeBron James stars as a fictionalized version of himself. (I feel weird for saying this, but LeBron showed more emotion than Michael Jordan did in the original. MJ seemed wooden and had hardly any emotion when he met the Looney Tunes. LeBron was legit excited to meet Bugs Bunny and treated him like a buddy.) At a young age, LeBron was taught that basketball is all work and no play.Fast forward to present day, he wants his children to follow in his footsteps, but his son, Dominic "Dom" wants to create video games. One day, LeBron and his family are invited to the Warner Bros. To discuss a movie deal, but when he and his son get into an argument, an evil computer A. I. named Al-G Rhythm abducts them and forces LeBron to play a high stakes basketball game against video game characters that his son created. Al-G gives LeBron 24 hours to put together a team, so he's sent to Looney Tune World and teams up with Bugs Bunny to put together the ultimate team. LeBron wants big powerful characters like Superman, King Kong and the Iron Giant, but Bugs just wants to get his ol' tune pals back together.This becomes one of the best scenes in the movie. LeBron, and Bugs visit other Warner Bros. Produced films to find all the remaining Looney Tunes. I won't spoil all the surprises. If LeBron and his team loses, then Al-G will take his son prisoner and abduct anyone who is livestreaming it on their cell phone. Welcome to the jam!If you grew up with the original, I implore you to give this new one a try. I was skeptical for awhile, but when I finally saw it, I really enjoyed it and I felt like a kid again. I highly recommend SPACE JAM: A NEW LEGACY!!!

In watching this film, I got a "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" kinda vibe with Warner Brothers properties all over it. Now to be honest, I didn't watch the first one, but I didn't think that mattered. The idea was simple - a kid who didn't want to be like famous dad whose dad wanted him to be like famous dad. But it's 2020..or so and tech is big so he wants to be a tech designer. So that makes him ripe to convince that he should join that side because his famous dad doesn't care, etc.Okay, so with this when they get through the 'toon-town' thing and to the big basketball game, there is TON of HBOmax and Warner Brothers & their acquired properties in the audience and to be honest, I spent my time identifying them. "Oooh, there's Frankenstein Jr!!!" while those very young ones 6 to 10 years old and a few adults watching the movie with me were asking, "What or who is Frankenstein Jr.?" ...of which was the same kinda thing when I watched "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" and I asked some adults "Who is Betty Boop?" It's that kinda film.Be prepared - all the 'cancel culture' broo-ha-ha is not there. It's just a Warner Brothers cartoon film for kids and those who like basketball, and a B-I-G promotion fest for the adults who catch onto it all. I ranked it higher than most reviews placed here because I liked the seeing the cartoons, and putting the live and cartoon properties in the audience of the big game.

Review title: Only for kids and those easily suckered into crossovers
Review_body: As someone who grew up with the original, I was very disappointed with this so-called "sequel". LeBron James is a horrible actor (Michael Jordan was as well, but at least he made it believable), the film is basically a shameless crossover, which becomes its only selling point, and unfortunately, the film lacks the heart and charisma that made the original Space Jam a cult classic. Only recommended for kids or those who are easily suckered into crossovers.

Watched Space Jam: A New Legacy with LeBron James as Himself, Cedric Joe as Dom James, Don Cheadle(Avengers:Endgame,Falcon And The Winter Soldier) as AI-G Rhythm , Michael B. Jordan(Black Panther) as Himself ,Sue Bird as Herself, Draymond Green as Himself, Anthony Davis as The Brow, Damian Lillard as Chronos , Klay Thompson as Wet-Fire, Nneka Ogwumike as Arachnneka , Diana Taurasi as White Mamba, Jeff Bergmen(Looney Tunes:Rabbits Run) as Bugs Bunny , Eric Bauza(Looney Tunes Coach Daffy) as Daffy Duck Aka Coach Daffy , Candi Milo(New Looney Tunes) as Granny, Bob Bergen(Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast) as Tweety ,Jeff Bergmen(The Lego Movie) as Sylvester The Cat ,Zendaya(Spider-Man:Far From Home) as Lola Bunny and Rosario Dawson(The Mandalorian) as DCEU Wonder Woman.Not as Good as The Original but still Fun a Movie and Enjoyed LeBron James basically Space Jam Meets Ready Player One i enjoyed the references to the Stuff in Warner Brothers IP also enjoyed the seeing The King James Montage of his career to The Present from Cleveland to Miami Back to Cleveland and now in LA for the Lakeshow. Also since we have reopened the common theme of 2021 in Film & TV has been Family.,Score By Kris Bowers (Green Book), Cinematography By Salvatore Totino(Spider-Man Homecoming) ,Direction By Malcom D. Lee(Undercover) Ready Player Jam 7/10.

Review title: People Are Expecting Too High And Take It So Seriously
Review_body: People are expecting too high and take it so seriously on this, what would you expect? It's already says LeBron James, but you guys are expecting Leonardo DiCaprio type of acting in this film, and then people are thinking that when they showing all the Warner Bros. Property is just for advertisement, but i found it as a fun cameo, what happen to people?, Space Jam A New Legacy isn't fills with the greatest acting of all time especially for LeBron James, but for a debut from a basket player is good enough, the movie fills with an amazing animation, visual and special effects, Space Jam A New Legacy is a very fun movie, it's entertaining, it's enjoyable, just watch it and enjoy it, and if you wanna review, judge it and give a score, please don't expect too high, at in the end is LeBron James.

Overlong and unfunny, Malcolm D. Lee's 'Space Jam: A New Legacy' is no slam dunk. In contrast to 'Space Jam' (1996), which successfully integrates Michael Jordan with Looney Tunes cartoon characters, the screenplay for 'Space Jam: A New Legacy' frequently ignores the presence of Bugs Bunny and his companions. These animated figures are just referenced in passing and never play a significant role in the storyline of the film.

Review title: Basically a Remake of a Film that Wasn't Great to Begin with
Review_body: I'll be honest right off the bat and say that I've only seen the original Space Jam a total of two times. I find it to be mildly enjoyable, but it wasn't a film I ever latched onto. The nostalgia of the 90s is all over it and that's what makes it entertaining to this day, but I still don't think it's great. When I heard they would be making a very loose sequel and Lebron James wasn't going to be filling the shoes that Michael Jordan left, I was intrigued. With the technology today, this concept could be big and fun. Well, Space Jam: A New Legacy definitely had its moments, but it's ultimately just the same concept all over again. Here's why, unless you're showing it to your kids, it's really not that special.Here's the premise in a nutshell. Lebron James is having issues connecting with his son Dom and has nothing in mind for him but that he wants to make him a basketball star just like himself. After stumbling across a room on the Warner Bros. Lot, Lebron and his son are sucked into what the film calls the "server-verse". This is where all the worlds from the movies Warner Bros. Have ever made all exist. Being sent to the land of Looney Tunes by Al G. Rhythm, who runs the so-called "server-verse" and has challenged Lebron to a basketball game in exchange for his freedom, comes across Bugs Bunny. Bugs then helps Lebron assemble the rest of the "Tune Squad" and the second half of the movie is basically the basketball game.Other than some incredibly impressive visuals and a fun soundtrack, there really isn't much substance here. It's really just a story of a father winning the love back from his son. For that, this film is not that engaging and the screenplay is very, very standard as well. The final act of the film goes on way too long and it just felt like a massive commercial for Warner Bros. As a company. At least all their famous movies are good and have memorable characters, right?As far as the positives go, Don Cheadle as Al G. Rhythm completely held the movie together for me. His over-the-top and campy performance made me smile and he's in a lot more of the movie than I expected. I also really enjoyed the portion of the film where Lebron became a cartoon character with the rest of the Looney Tunes. That aspect was not a part of the original film and I found that to be a very nice addition. Other than that though, Space Jam: A New Legacy really doesn't have anything that suggests it needed to be made.In the end, the life lessons for kids throughout this film have all been done better in other family films. The aspect of meshing Looney Tunes with live-action Basketball still kind of has its charm, but again, the movie just feels like a giant corporate commercial. Lebron James is fine in the movie because he's in his element, but he's not the best actor overall. I smiled a few times and loved a cameo that occurs in the latter half of the film, but it wasn't enough to warrant a recommendation from me. It's just not that good of a movie. If you're a fan of the original, I'm sure you'll find moments to enjoy here, but it ultimately feels like a tired premise when looking back.

Review title: It doesn't know what it's appeal is...
Review_body: The original 'Space Jam' wasn't a good movie at all but it benefits from being the time capsule movie of the 90's. The color palette, the pop culture references, the product placements and Jordan cement it as a classic, an undeserved classic but a classic nonetheless. 'Space Jam: A New Legacy' pretends the original never existed, a fatal flaw. The prime selling point of the picture is nostalgia. It doesn't do LeBron James any favors pretending that he isn't in the shadow of Michael Jordan. It's debatable who the better basketball star is but 'Space Jam' is Jordan's.We live in a nostalgic age. We're constantly revisiting 90's IPs and I don't have a problem with that. The only thing relevant to the original is the title. It's a shame too because I think a lot of humor could have been generated by being Meta about the comparisons between James and Jordan and why there needed to be a new 'Space Jam'.LeBron James is the star of the film. I know that he is reviled as much as he is loved and brings a lot of baggage with him. I think a lot of the hate he has received is totally unfounded but 'Space Jam' too isn't going to help his reputation. Jordan wasn't Brando but he looks like it in comparison to James who is awkward and wooden. It doesn't help that the moral of the story about being yourself is so heavy handed and LeBron doesn't stop hammering it in. I'm sure this isn't the case but he looks like an egotist because there is no selfparody or sense of humor to his performance. He spends a great deal of his screen time lecturing the Looney Tunes. I'm sorry but not only is this going to strike out with the millennial but the kids are going to hate it too.The set up to the ball game is overly complicated and Don Cheadle's villain is given no reason to hate James or exist. We just see Warner products everywhere. I don't mind this in theory as a few of the film's only laughs come from revisiting these properties. They don't join the game or comment on it though. They just are there for you to pause it and gawk at them.They needed to bring back Jordan. The movie doesn't work without him. It could have been the perfect opportunity for the two NBA legends to celebrate both their achievements and show they had a sense of humor. Instead this is probably LeBron's biggest disaster since 'The Decision' while Jordan's legend grows with 'The Last Dance'

I enjoyed this about as much as the first Space Jam but other than that I really was entertained watching this, the looney tunes were funny and entertaining.References to other Warner brother movies during the main basketball match I noticed with a Michael Jordan joke and 3 refrences to the first Space Jam.LeBron James was pretty good in the movie and talking to the looney tunes like they are there, the fully animated scenes were really well animated and voice acted.

Disjointed, sparratic and heartless. Jokes felt like a adhd nightmare with out of touch humor. So many moments of warner just flexing, it completely rips the storys flow and coherentness. Maybe deep down it has something genuine, but its covered by so many excecutive adjustments its nowhere to be seen.2/10: terrabad.

"Space Jam: A New Legacy" is not a masterpiece, but is not a bad film either, just fun and nostalgic about "Looney Tunes", also is full of cameos of famous Warner Bros. Characters (animated and real ones). The script is not that original, but the special effects are good and the animation is cool. A fun film for nostalgic people like me.

It is full of reference to the Warner universe and from the beginning makes it clear to the public, that is, a self-promotion for the studio and King, that being said, any attempt to speak ill of these aspects is unfounded, it is made for it , which is very honest. However, it lacks a lot in the story, it is shallow despite surprising in its references to The Matrix, It a Thing, Harry Potter, King Kong, Rick and Morty, Game of Thrones, Superman, Wonder Woman and the rest of the Justice League, brings excitement for that aspect.The shared universe is well done, both in animation and in CGI. Warner wanted to show its potential and got it, of course it's not a 10, but it's good. Unfortunately there are flaws in the plot, for example: spoiler: it doesn't explain the real reason why Bugs' friends leave his world and in the end decide to come back.It's not focused to be a sequel, even though it has a mention of the previous movie, it's just similar (that doesn't make the movie bad).When I went to see it I thought it would be a cheap copy of the old one, I had low expectations and didn't expect much, however, it has its original aspects, a different feel and new pop culture reference, it's not the Looneys that need help anymore, but the LeBron James.The acting was relatively good, but Don Cheadle left something to be desired because of his character without depth, a classic villain, where, it has no sense for what he does, nothing interesting, they could have at least given a little sense to value the actor. .It surpassed my expectations, but not really a grandiose one (nor is it its goal), but just a fun movie that implements good references, great to watch with the family.Film viewed from the 27th to the 28th of August 2021.

Review title: Nominate LeBron James for the Raspberry Award
Review_body: This is a very bad movie. It has bad writing. Bad acting. The comedy is extremely unfunny in a weird way. For example, Marvin the Martian has a ray gun setting that goes to "Ray Charles," I mean...what is funny about that? The animation isn't terrible but it is not enough to hold the movie together. LeBron James himself gives a truly awful performance. He should never act again.

Review title: Shamelessly rehashes the original film and makes a poor attempt to appeal to all audiences
Review_body: "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is a standalone sequel to the 1996 animation/basketball themed film "Space Jam". Starring NBA player LeBron James in the lead role alongside Don Cheadle, it shamelessly rehashes the original film and makes a poor attempt to appeal to all audiences.In Burbank, California, NBA superstar LeBron James and his son Dom (Cedric Joe) are sucked into a virtual world by Warner Bros.' high-tech A. I. program Al-G Rhythm (Don Cheadle). Taking Dom prisoner, Al-G promises to return him if LeBron is able to assemble a basketball team consisting of Warner Bros. Characters and beat him in a match against his own set of players. LeBron hastily agrees and is sent off flying into the virtual universe where he lands in "Tune World", meeting with a solitary Bugs Bunny. LeBron informs the famous cartoon rabbit of his predicament and they both agree to recruit the rest of the Looney Tunes to form their own unique basketball team to defeat Al-G once and for all.I suppose it's just my own morbid curiosity but I have a habit of greatly anticipating sequels to films that have been in development for an extended period of time. They can be worth the wait, like "Blade Runner 2049", which added so much more to its already established lore, or a complete disappointment, like "Independence Day: Resurgence", which was little more than a cash-grab rehash. "Space Jam: A New Legacy", or as I'm calling it, "Ready Player LeBron" is the latter example, doing what the original did that made it something of a cult favourite amongst 90s kids but simply applying to it a deceptive new paint job.I'm not going to act like the 1996 film was perfect, as watching it back today made me realise how badly it has aged. It was basically just a giant ad filled with Nike shoes, McDonald's Fries, and bottles of Gatorade. It also doesn't help that the now disgraced R. Kelly sang the film's theme song. With that said, it was still an amusing concept for the time, and besides, ads can still be fun to watch if they are marketed correctly. This follow-up, which comes to us a quarter of a century later, is also a giant ad, albeit, in a different sense of the word. Instead of consumer items, here we are being advertised various different IPs (Intellectual Properties) belonging to Warner Bros. Such as Harry Potter, the DC Universe, Game Of Thrones, and even The Matrix. Oh, and the Looney Tunes are in there as well in case you didn't notice by now. Normally I would love to see all of these IPs crossing over but here it's handled so poorly that I ended up dreading seeing all these different universes merging. This is because there's no sense of organisation with combining everything together, it is all carelessly thrown in there as a means for Warner Bros. To show off how many of these IPs they own the rights to. In other words, the company appears more preoccupied with being dominant over what its audience should enjoy rather than merely wishing to entertain us with some of its characters.The film is at least decent to look at, with state-of-the-art CGI effects that do a serviceable job of combining 2D cartoons with 3D environments. However, the parts I liked best were the ones where an animated LeBron James was in Tune World interacting with Bugs Bunny and the others. It's so rare to see traditionally hand-drawn animation these days, or at least a style that replicates it efficiently, so I guess that's why scenes like these stood out to me the most.
