That's not to say the 3D animated Looney Tunes looked terrible, although they did look a bit creepy at times, I'm just more of a fan of old school animation and the charm that comes with it.Additionally, I can't tell if it's the lazy script or bad comic timing but the film just isn't that funny. Considering the Looney Tunes are supposed to be some of the funniest cartoon characters of all time, it's a huge shame to see all their antics fall flat here. Taking the place of the slapstick humour we are used to are dated Matrix parodies, which haven't been relevant in over twenty years, and Porky Pig rapping, calling himself "The Notorious P. I. G.". Of course, I am aware this film's target audience is young children but how many of them are actually going to understand any of these references? Surely the filmmakers can't expect to have their parents explain every single pop culture joke to them? In total, I think there were only two parts of the entire movie I found amusing, one was a reference to a certain meme of Bugs Bunny impersonating Elmer Fudd and the other alluding to why Michael Jordan declined to return to make this sequel. The reason I am not elaborating further is because in the event that a parent who is reading this ends up dragged along to watch the film with their kid and wants something to laugh at won't have it spoiled for them.Although he's obviously not an actor by trade, I think LeBron James was able to hold his own throughout the film. I don't follow basketball so I'm not sure what type of person James is off court but here he seems like a sincere person at heart who cares about other people. His acting is surprisingly better than I expected too, which gives the impression he must have taken some lessons in order to effectively play this fictionalised version of himself. As for Don Cheadle, his character is just a generic cartoonish villain wanting nothing more than for an excuse to show off his excess power (sounds a lot like Warner Bros. Itself if you ask me). He only exists to set up the big basketball match at the end, never really feeling as though he is huge threat in the long run. Though to Cheadle's credit, he at least looks like he's having fun playing the role.In the end, "Ready Player LeBron", sorry, I mean "Space Jam: A New Legacy", was not worth waiting the extensive twenty-five years it took to get made. It does exactly what a sequel shouldn't do in rehashing the entire basic plot structure of the original while trying to pass itself off as something completely new. Upon some research, there were apparently some spin-offs considered in place of this film such as skateboarding with Tony Hawk or golfing with Tiger Woods. Those would have been much better ideas than what we got here so if there's another follow-up in the future, let's hope they follow that format instead.I rate it 4/10.

25 years following one of the most polarizing cult classic sport movies from the 90s, Space Jam, Warner Bros has finally released its long awaited sequel. Directed by Malcolm D. Lee and Terence Nance and starring NBA all star Lebron James alongside the Looney Tunes gang, the film has been garnishing countless attention from former fans of the first movie and the general public alike. As of now, it's been going rather smoothly at the box office and on HBO Max, despite not being met with the nicest critical reception. So as a non fan of the first film, let's see how this followup has been presented in 2021.The main plot centers around a fictionalized LeBron James teaming up with the original Looney Tunes cast in order to win a basketball game against a rogue artificial intelligence that has kidnapped his son. Just like the first film, the plot is utterly bizarre past the point of comprehension, especially when we consider the massive time lap. What makes the plot even worse is how rushed the pacing is just to make it to the game, and if you're unfamiliar with the Looney Tunes or much of the movie references the writers implement to signify their new presence, you'd feel utterly lost. It doesn't help that for a movie that could easily tackle how badly artificial intelligence has ruined the progress of human knowledge within the entertainment business, it would rather make it all about the cliched and predictable storyline of James trying to understand his own flesh and blood. Needless to say, the plot feels like a failure in the making.However, as fundamentally flawed as the whole movie is, it might actually be fully aware of all of its problems. As this is a long awaited continuation from a ridiculous corporate cash grab, it never takes itself too seriously enough to allow the insanity of a project like this run wild. Because this movie mostly takes place within a Warners streaming verse, much of the plot relies on the gimmick of product placements to serve the function of James and the Looney Tunes taking down an AI. While the actual game plot gets a little underwhelming due to the predictable outcome, there are still plenty of gags and bizarre turnarounds that are too unbelievable to look away from. Also, if there is any group from the crew that clearly had a ball on this, it would be the animation team led by veteran WB animator Spike Brandt, as they really capture the timeless comedic nature and poses in the lovable Warner Bros characters that we have all cherished for decades onward. Even in CGI, the talents of the gifted animators can never be outmatched with the right amount of craftsmanship and love.On a side note, while Lebron isn't that great of an actor in his own right, he does seem to at least take the movie about as seriously as it needs to be, so any hoaky underacting can be attributed to the nature of the film more than anything else. In addition, Don Cheadle must have been having a ball as the AI during the making of the feature, as he disguises his truly despicable pettiness with a sly charming persona to a believable point. Also, it's incredible to see how far famed voice actor Eric Bauza has come in voicing Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Marvin the Martian and many more, as his wonderfully sharp range brings the characters to life very solidly. Other veterans like Jeff Bergman, Bob Bergen, Candi Milo fit right back into their character perfectly, but it is noticeably peculiar having celebrities like Zendaya voicing Lola Bunny, Fortunately, she does bring a certain level of charisma that was much needed for a character that had already grown better in other media. It's funny comparing non actors, in this case basketball players, to professional actors and VAs, but that's what movies like this are for.So even though Space Jam: A New Legacy is far from a great movie, it didn't really disappoint in being what it set out to do in the first place. While it's obviously not going to win everyone over, there's a good chance fans of the first film will find the most value out of it and even share them with new people like their own kids (c'mon, it's been 25 years since then). Unless you're more in the mood to check out Black Widow or you hate the first film with a passion, I'd say this wouldn't be the worst flick to take your family to on a lazy weekend. Besides, we haven't had this much fun in the movie theaters in a long time.

The quality of this movie is off the charts, in terms of computer graphics. I'll give it that much.However, it's just not that watchable (it literally took me 4 times because I just kept wanting to do anything but keep watching this movie, in most scenes, not to bash it, but just to be honest).Also, is LeBron that special? I see people who are great at lots of things but they sure don't get THAT much praise. A movie just shouldn't praise one guy so much unless it's a documentary.The ending with all of the different Warner characters is pretty good, however, but not great.Don Cheadle does a great job in his acting and role, also (as usual), and this should be noted. He really is a great actor, and sells the part of the villain nicely (I can't see anyone doing it better, actually). If Hollywood has any more bad guy roles, there's your guy (or at least a very solid one)!I feel like Six Flags could've made it into the movie more, besides one funny line, though.

Review title: Feels more like an advert of Warner Bros. promoting their properties
Review_body: The original Space Jam was a childhood favourite of mine. Even though that film doesn't hold as well now, it's still much better than Space Jam: A New Legacy.Space Jam: A New Legacy follows LeBron James as he works with the Looney Tunes to win a basketball game in order to save his son from a rogue artificial intelligence.Looking back at Space Jam now, it's not very good but there is a certain charm that film possesses and a level of nostalgia for me which makes it a guilty pleasure. However, I found no joy watching Space Jam: A New Legacy. I was interested purely because of nostalgia but this film disappointed me on so many levels. It doesn't even feel like a film. It's more of a 2 hour advertisement for all the properties Warner Bros own. We're taken through franchises like The Matrix, Austin Powers, the DC universe and many more throughout. It felt like a cheap way to promote and sell their properties. Even the audience of the basketball match is made up of characters Warner Bros own. The huge amount of characters and references were so distracting and took away my focus on the actual game. The story of the original Space Jam was very cheesy and predictable but it came from a time where it was more acceptable. Here, the premise is so outdated and predictable all the way through. Aside from one, every single joke fell flat. The only aspect of Space Jam: A New Legacy that I thought was well done were the effects. Clearly a lot of effort went into them and the film indeed looks great.The performances are also pretty awful. Michael Jordan's performance in the original was not good and the same goes for LeBron James. This film revolves around him more than the Looney Tunes themselves but James isn't able to carry this film. He is very wooden especially during scenes that require him to show emotion. It's evidently clear that he's not an actor. Don Cheadle looks like he's having a lot of fun playing the villain but the script unfortunately doesn't work in his favour. The Looney Tunes were fine but I felt like they weren't utilised to their full potential here.Space Jam: A New Legacy is a film to forget. The script is very cringey and predictable, the acting isn't good and it lacks the charm and fun of the original. This is simply a massive promotion for Warner Bros and nothing else.

IN A NUTSHELL:
A rogue artificial intelligence kidnaps the son of famed basketball player LeBron James, who then has to work with Bugs Bunny to win a basketball game. There are some entertaining moments for sure, but it's one gigantic commercial for Warner Brothers IP properties, which is a huge turnoff for most viewers. The target audience is definitely kids. Their parents who grew up watching the original movie might be annoyed and let down.The film is directed by Malcolm D. Lee. Are you Team Tune or Team Goon? This is a spoiler-free movie review.THINGS I LIKED:
If you're a LeBron James fan, you'll love this movie because it features him, showcasing a bunch of real-life clips from his historical career.If you're a Warner Brothers cartoon character fan, you'll love seeing all of your favorites. Berg Bergen is the only voice actor to return from the original Space Jam movie of 1996.Academy Award nominee Don Cheadle is great, as expected. He was just nominated for an Emmy for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series. Good on him. He's a wonderful actor and he seemed to have a lot of fun with his role in this film. He plays AL G. Rythm (algorithm)
There's a lot of humor, although not all of it lands. LeBron is good about letting them take a lot of jabs at him and his career.Tons of fun movie references and clips of film classics like Superman: The Movie, Batman (1989), Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, THE MATRIX, The Wizard of Oz, Mad Max: Fury Road, Wonder Woman, and soooo many more.If you're not that much into basketball, there are still plenty of non-basketball shenanigans to enjoy.TONS of fun Easter Eggs! Look closely!Lots of entertaining cameo performances and voice talents from other sports stars like Sue Bird, Anthony Davis, Draymond Green, Damian Lillard, Nneka Ogwumike, Diana Taurasi, and so many more.There's an awesome Michael Jordan gag that actually made me laugh out loud. Loved it.It's super entertaining to look at the audience during the big game to pick out all kinds of characters from zillions of Warner Brothers movies.I've always loved movies that combine animation with real-life actors. I enjoyed the different animation styles.The movie features the huge E3 conference. One of my sons competed in that when he was in college. He now does art design on video games at Blizzard!If you love basketball, you'll get a kick out of the "server-verse" version of the game.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
Warner Brothers promotes itself HARD in this movie.As great as LeBron James is at basketball, he's not a very good actor. I don't think anyone is very surprised by that, but it's a shame because LeBron is in almost every scene in the movie.The movie tries to cram WAY too much into every scene.Visually, it's sometimes hard to catch everything because things fly by so fast and furiously.The explanation at the very end of the movie about the demise of a certain character was incredibly lame and lazy writing.There is some super cheesy writing as well.Warner Brothers cartoon fans have already been complaining that we don't see enough of the cartoons. I disagree. There is plenty of cartoon chaos.All of the Extras in the audience during the game don't always react correctly to what's actually happening in the game. It just looks like they were filmed cheering to be inserted into the scenes later, which of course they were. I'm just saying that it really looks like it.The soundtrack isn't as good as the first movie.The plot is just silly with ridiculously high stakes.TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Lots of cartoon violence.Mild profanity. One character is obviously spewing profanities in one scene, but they humorously get bleeped out.There are a lot of references to R-rated movies that kids won't understand or recognize.You can see my full movie review on my Movie Review Mom YouTube channel!

I gave this a shot but it's pretty rough. The acting is much worse than the first and the script is bad too. My wife liked the pop culture references and my almost 2 year old was drawn to the colors but that's about it.

Review title: Studios Need To Step Their Game Up
Review_body: Why call it Space Jam when it has nothing to do with space? Besides a couple of laughs and some half decent visuals, this movie is pretty bad. The whole father and son arc was incredibly weak and predictable, and used as a device so Lebron didn't have to actually carry the weight of acting, because damn his acting was wooden, and so was the dialogue, and the story for that matter. Don Cheadle couldn't even bring that terrible writing to life. The film takes so long to get to where the audience wants it to go, and then it tries to bedazzle you with lights and characters galore, the background characters (like Pennywise, Batman, The Mask) looked so awkward. Why are audiences becoming happier with mediocre films these days? I think Netflix is lowering peoples standards.

Review title: too boring, no escapism, is too bland
Review_body:
When you see lebron and his son you expect to be at least engaging. But even that feels formulaic.And being a blockbuster, no one want to see inside a machine...is too boring and the jokes are flat, like the kevin hart joke(who asked for that)
ive tried to watch but is too much vfx, and not so much story, even bugs say''a nba star needs my help, i feel like happened before''...when a movie jokes about itself, you know is bad.lebron cant play.is a bad actor.

I honestly didn't expect LeBron James to be that bad at acting. Like really bad. I thought he pretty much ruined the movie. After this I don't see him having much of an acting career. On the brighter side it was definitely cool seeing all the old Looney Toones in the movies again. I especially liked seeing all the Warner Bros characters in the stands. Not a totally terrible film because of all the old characters, but damn LeBron was horrible. 5 stars.

It's Definitely an improvement over the first movie. Sure he's not a.great actor but as good or better then Jordan in that department, side characters were funny and toons had some good jokes/Gags as well. Def worth the watch or paying to go see it.

Not as bad as I expected but still not good enough for pass marks. Bugs sounds like bugs (sometimes). It fails with the authenticity, CGI is not great it works but *only when necessary.PS Release Pepe the PC brigade are pathetic.
The film was strictly for children if u have a brain this isn't for you. The animations and visuals are great but everything is else is bad. Better to skip this than watch it.

Review title: Harsh Critics.... The Movie isn't bad
Review_body: If you watch Michael Jordan's Space Jam compared to this movie it's really not that bad. Neither of the movies have a great acting from athletes that's why they are athletes are not actors. But it had great effects and I guess story line between a father and a son and I also thought that LeBron James did a good job of allowing some fun to be poked at him. I'm not the biggest fan of LeBron James at all but have to say I enjoyed the movie. Good family fun.
This movie was just pure terrible. Lebron is a great basketball player terrible actor. This movie was a disaster.

I'm 10 minutes in and I already know this movie is made for Lebron James by Lebron James, and you can't tell me otherwise.He is stiff, has weird line delivery.. but by God he is the greatest man ever born!!! He has flaws, but by the end, you know he will be what he needs to be : a self-named King (sarcasm).And with that, you know this can't be a good movie. It's passionless.The plot is simplistic and almost non-existent. A game to solve a family problem, period. Magical technology with ugly CGI of animated characters (Lola looks SO bad). Worst of all, is that they show you they have access to all the Warner Brother properties.. but aside from cheap references and background characters (ala "Ready Player One"), they just end up drafting the Looney Tunes to be underused. It's not even fun at doing what they wanted to do. I can't imagine this being even for kids to enjoy.It's sort of embarrassing.

Review title: I think it's better than what people are saying about it.
Review_body: I know it's a flawed movie, but I had fun with. Got laughs from Granny, Gossamer, Foghorn Leghorn and some production errors. Plus the world building here is better than the world building in the first Space Jam.You gotta get credit were credit is due.
Oh man it is really bad this movie. The one of Michael Jordan it is a millon times better. I didn't laugh not even once. It seemed like they were promoting hbo max by showing all of their characters.

Space Jam 2: A new Legacy
2021
U
Director: Malcolm D. Lee
Starring: Lebron James, Don Cheadle, Cedric Joe, Khris Davis, Sonequa Martin - Grace, Jeff Bergman, Zendaya, Gabriel Iglesias, Eric Bauza, Candi Milo, Bob Bergen, Fred Tatasciore etc
Space Jam 2: A new legacy is about a rogue artificial intelligence who kidnaps the son of the famed basketball player Lebron James. Who then has to work with Bugs Bunny and the rest of the looney tunes to win a basketball game in order to get his son back. I absolutely hated this film with a passion, and it was nothing more than an embarrassing cash grab from Warner brothers.My first of the few positives would be the nostalgia, the fun opening scene. The basketball elements and decent character background. The film did manage to achieve brief moments of nostalgia for me. Whether it was the basketball scenes reminiscent of the original, the soundtrack or just seeing the looney tunes back in action, it did manage to have some nostalgic moments that entertained me. I also thought the opening scene was fun and provided some decent character background. The film worked at its best when it focused on the characters and the basketball without all of the other bells and whistles. It was nice to get some background into LeBron's character and how he interacted with his basketball coach as a kid, it set up what he would be like with his own son in the present well.Now for my first few negatives. The set up was very generic, as well as the villain. The script and dialogue were terrible, as well as the performances and warner brothers using the film as promotion. The set up was so incredibly basic and predictable. Having the worn trope of having a son who doesn't feel accepted by his father for not wanting to do the same thing as him has been used so many times beforehand and didn't kick the film off in a good way at all. The villain was also incredibly generic. Think of the most simple motivations and reasoning behind a character's actions and that's what you had here, not even the charms of Don Cheadle could stop the poor writing behind this. The script and dialogue were also unfortunately very bad. It was forced, corny and never felt realistic. The dialogue was awkwardly executed, and you could tell even the actors were struggling to deliver the lines well, the script was simple and poorly constructed, it felt like no effort was put into making it even serviceable and it really effected the film. I do also have to say the performances were not very good. LeBron James seems like a likeable person, but his performance was terrible here. He delivered his lines in a forced and awkward manner and it all felt clunky and robotic, with no chemistry with the rest of the cast. I also thought this was just promotion for Warner Brothers. This didn't really feel like a space jam film. It felt like egotistical and desperate promotion of Warner Brothers IP. With no effort to even cover it up. Going as far as having some scenes within the studios really shows where the studio had there priorities with this film.My final few positives would be the animation, the voice cast and character designs, as well as the fun scenes with the looney tunes. I thought the animation here for the looney tunes was excellent, due to improved CGI and just more attention to detail the designs of Bugs bunny and co were drastically improved and it was interesting to see them so well designed. I also thought the cinematography here was great. It was largely used as a distraction, but the film bounced off the screen with its fun and creative worlds and futuristic visuals that were a visual delight. I also thought the voice cast was excellent, it was great to hear all of the original cast return in there glory, with a great new addition with Zendaya who bought Lola Bunny to life in a much better representation of her character then the original. I also thought the character designs for the looney tunes opposing teams were fun. Combining famous basketball players with different animals was a fun idea, they looked great and posed a good threat to the main plot point and the team. Finally, there was also a lot of fun scenes with recruiting the looney tunes. Despite Warner Brothers using the film as promotion, the scenes involving the looney tunes being trapped in different brands were admittedly very entertaining to watch and some of the best parts of the film.My next few negatives would be corny tone and humour. The rushed pacing, as well as the repetitive conflict and odd character decisions. This film rushed over so many things, any form of development or important scene introduced was just rushed over, never giving the audience time for any of it to connect or sink in, so therefore I just didn't care about the characters, I also thought the humour was terrible, I understand it's a family film. But the humour was incredibly forced, awkward and just fell flat. It was incredibly corny and was just trying too hard to be cool or funny and it just came across as cringy. I also thought the conflict here was extremely repetitive, having the son not feel accepted by Lebron was fine and it was clear his passion wasn't in basketball. But when the same lines and repetitive reasoning for the conflict was used so often without any form of development or just more to it, it just stayed in the same place and therefore it got tedious and repetitive. Plus, the son made some very questionable character decisions, the film made it come across like he hated his dad, without enough development between there relationship, so the son actually came across as naïve and extremely unlikeable, with illogical and harsh decisions throughout that made me even more disconnected to the relationships.My final few negatives would be the slow pacing in the second half, the lack of stakes or development to the plot. The awful 3D design of the looney tunes. And the messy final act. The film was easily thirty minutes too long, with a messy and clunky final act that dragged on for too long. The final basketball match was forty minutes long that's almost half the movie, and it didn't fly by it dragged along almost to the point of it being unwatchable. I also thought there was a complete lack of development or stakes to the plot. I never once considered the villain to be a threat or thought that there was a slight chance of the team actually losing, it was just predictably and simply laid out. With no development to the characters or further explanation into the villain. Finally, I thought the 3D designs for the looney tunes were terrible, I seriously don't understand why the creative team behind the film decided having 3D designs instead of 2D would work in the final act, because it didn't. Everyone looked poorly made and the designs were frankly off-putting and worked better with the original 2D designs. This didn't need to be changed and was a poorly executed creative decision.Overall, Space Jam 2 is mildly entertaining in parts, and it was nice to see the looney tunes back. And will probably be mostly entertaining for young kids. But it was an embarrassing cash grab from Warner Brothers. It was lazy, forced and completely cringy. Another failed sequel to a classic that should have never been made. Warner Brothers, there is a difference between trying and trying too hard and this fell completely flat.Overall rating 27/100.

Review title: I can see why the critics hated it
Review_body: It's a giant bragfest for Lebron, rubbing his wealth in everyone's face, his basketball success, making his kid look like a super genius...oh yeah, he's also a super basketball player.No one is sympathetic, but quite honestly in this world, that's probably the most believable thing about the movie.Hard pass. No good.
This is not classic lonney tunes not fun like cartoon worst.

A crazy adventure movie
It is again about the return of the Loney Tunes to play with the great Lebron James, but this time it is the player who seeks them to recover his son after offending a digital system, sending him to the land of the Tunes and Bugs helps him to put the team together.Quality.Spectacular animation combines various styles.Completely copy the previous movie in this reboot, everything happens as is, only now they give it the technological touch, it feels totally implausible.It feels like a lot to sell, Warner brings out all of their licenses and characters in this movie for you to see on screen. Which gives it the most hype, that's what half the movie feels like.Typical jokes of the characters, but in less intensity.Ideal for the previous generations, the new ones do not entertain so much.Talk about the importance of family and the importance of listening and letting others be.An option to see if you like movie reboots.

Review title: YOU CANT BE GREAT WITHOUT PUTTING IN THE WORK!!
Review_body: Seeing the reviews on here I get the impression theyre from Michael Jordan fans, LeBron James haters and those who never saw the first film. Its a film thats very different in its set up but just as fun in its delivery.
LeBron is not MJ and this is a mess. Product placement over plot. Kids wanted to leave 10 minutes in.
How can you say this is soulless I mean come on this movie was pretty good my kids loved it ... I saw someone say they feel forced , dude you hating for no reason.

For all the characters and budget of this film is was a real let down to see this film turn out so poor.It is very obvious from the start and just seems like an advertising vehicle for the Warner brothers back catalogue.

Review title: 25 years later this movie achieved nothing
Review_body: This movie wasn't going to be good from the start ,but somehow it ends up being even worse then the original. We see LeBron james as a kid playing a gameboy he gets called out by his coach who tells that he need to truly apply himself if he want to succeed. Cut to the present LeBron wanting his sons to follow in his footsteps. He push them specifically his youngest son Dom. The Problem is Dom is a game designer and doesn't want to play basketball. And from that you know what's the arc and the resolution. How the looney tunes factor in is that while at Warner bros talking about a movie deal LeBron and Dom are under surveillance by the studios self-aware A.i Al-G Rhythm(Don Cheadle) who digitized them into the serververse a universe where all the Warner bros characters exist on different worlds and blah blah Son's kidnapped LeBron meets the toons and all their fate's rest in the hands of a basketball game. LeBron doesn't offer anything outside of his stardom. He is a horrible actor giving terrible line delivery almost as bad as Shaq. I'm not going to lie like most and say Michael's performance was gold material,but Michael was likeable. Despite his bland attitude you could a least enjoy his presence he knew what kind of movie he was in and made the best of it. Regardless on where you stand with LeBron he's not that he is a Jerk who want things his way the whole movie. An ass to his Son until the end when he gets the obvious lesson. The Toons are alright just as much they were in the orginal but they dont get much screen time before the game. The animation on all of them is good,The 3d design look great I would've preferred those to 2d redesign Honestly. The seververse is just a big advertisement for Warner. With DCEU posters everywhere,a whole ready player one scenario with the all these Studio characters that most casual audiences probably aren't even going to recognize or know. With terrible cosplayer standin on a repeated loop. Overall this a diaster of a film while it could've offered something with the serververse but the tired message, The product placement combine with LeBrons acting makes this a sleeper to get into the end with very few joke that actually worked this film can be forgotten* Spoiler/Plotholes* starts the basketball game starts to soon and last to long like 40 minutes. It's not even really a basketball game as opposed to a video game version of dom's creation. I guess also the first movie doesn't exist in this continuation because the toons live in a server not the center of the earth. They have no memory of Michael but they make jokes about him. Even the Nerdlucks show up. The defeat of Al G Rhythm has no repructions he's suppose to be the algorithm for the studio servers and controls the whole serververse wouldn't his death destroy the servers and all the characters? The whole bugs death is pointless, he's fine and how did he get into the human world?

The negative reviews seem to be made by individuals who either dislike Lebron or dislike animated kids movies. In that case this movie wasn't for you. If you watched this movie with an open mind you would've enjoyed. I watched old looney tunes cartoons growing up and I've also been a basketball fan my whole life. What some critics described as blatant advertising for other WB movies I thought was pretty creative and entertaining. The references weren't exactly to unheard of movies. And it's important to view this as a looney tunes movie with Lebron NOT a Lebron movie with looney tunes. Obviously Bron isn't the greatest actor but he did fine and it wasn't as bad as people are making out to be. At the end of the day this movie is for the kids, and not adult critics and movie reviewers. As long as you keep that in mind you'll be able to enjoy it. So ignore all the 1 ratings from haters.

Review title: Welcome to the Jam and the Looney!!!
Review_body: The first Space Jam will always be my favorite movies of all time.I love Space Jam so much, and I also love the Looney Tunes. The Tune Squad vs The Goon Squad was a pretty cool idea if you think about it. The movie was alright, but they also have a little bit of drama and there's also hilarious cameos as well. I love how they tell the story of LeBron James and his son, because this movie is like a father and son story, and the Looney Tunes will do anything to help LeBron get his son back from an evil super villain who played War Machine from the MCU, Don Cheadle. Space Jam: A New Legacy was alright, but still I really enjoyed the original Space Jam more and the Looney Tunes all together.Thank you for bringing the best Space Jam movie ever made!!!

Review title: If you love your kids take them to the original only
Review_body: This is what happens when someone lives in the shadow of another man. He wears the same number as him (23) tries to be like him (but end up being 4-7) then stars in the same movie as him (but flops). Kids don't be like prince james, be your own person. Oh, and this movie sucks.

I saw Space Jam: A New Legacy today on HBO Max & I thought it was a Good Movie. Like a lot of 90s Kids I Grew up With The Original 1996 Movie & I thought this was gonna be Great & it was Just as Good as the Original. The Movie has a lot of references to The Matrix & a lot WB Movies & Tv Shows. LeBron James did a Good job as Himself & Zendaya did A Awesome Job as Lola Bunny. People where Complaining about how Porky Pig Raps & I will admit that was A little Cringey but besides that I enjoyed this Movie so 8/10 from Me :)

This new movie has great special effects, that's probably the highest praise I can give this CGI fest, which is forgettable at best, a waste of time at worst.The Michael Jordan movie might not be a classic, but this one is a bad movie.
Uninteresting mess ,Bad movie , nothing to do with the original Space Jam and Michael Jordan which is absolutely great.2/10.

The 1st was tragic, but in a fun, tongue-in-cheek way- but this? I can't fathom for the life of me why anyone felt this was necessary or needed, but it most definitely was not.It feels like a whiny, narcissistic need to be something, but unless the goal of that something is a hot pile of garbage, the filmmakers/actors/producers missed the mark by a hot mile.You cannot spend every waking minute lecturing from your ivory tower; telling us lowly plebs what horrible, deplorable people we are, and then have the gall to expect us to toss money your direction for something because, once again, you seem to be laboring under the delusion that you're the GOAT, and guess what? You are not the GOAT.I'm delighted to see the rating as low as it is- currently hovering around 3.5 stars- that tells me a large swath of film watchers also find this hackneyed gobbledygook a complete heIIscape of worthlessness. The only way this rating comes up is troll armies arriving to prop up this ridiculous nonsense.Maybe try China, Mr. James. You seem quite focused on their approval, along with the rest of your league.

Space Jam: A New Legacy is a sequel 25 years too late. Trying to bring back the nostalgia and success of the 1996 original, this new one lacks the charm and charisma of the original. In the end, this one feels desperate on throwing so much crap at the wall to see if something lands and sticks, and it lacks the heart and ambition making it a big cashgrab without direction.That being said, I don't think it has zero merit. When the Looney Tunes Classic 2D Animation sequence of the film comes up, it looks pretty good and has a bit of fun with what it does with slapstick humour and references. There are Warner Bros. References to franchises everywhere, which makes it feel like Ready Player One, so at first it's kind of cool but then you realise it's going to throw this at you non-stop and starts to get tedious. Little glimpses of humour are okay and the voice actors do a good job with the characters.All the live-action/human actor sequences however are really bad. To be fair, Michael Jordan was kind of bad too, but he had more depth to him than LeBron James did and was acting at cartoon sequences to nothing. Don Cheadle is really the only actor seemingly having a blast with it. Everybody else acts poorly and there's not really a Bill Murray or Wayne Knight equivalent here to add in some good banter. I didn't buy the kid was a computer genius either, not helped by poor acting.Its Soundtrack was lacking here too. It's one of the very best things going for the original Space Jam and fitted well with the themes and style of the film. Here there's nothing memorable and just seems generic and forgettable. The film relies mostly on CGI visuals and by the end becomes complete and utter nonsense of going too far off the rails for my liking personally, especially with no firm rules.In the end, it wasn't the worst watch in the whole wide world, but it felt like it was trying too hard and lacked what made the original Space Jam appealing and become a Guilty Pleasure. Yes it was nice to see the Looney Tunes again, but this is not the great big comeback for them and all the money in the world and cameos in it don't mean alot if the film isn't hitting the right notes for new and nostalgic fans.4.5/10.

Space Jam: A New Legacy®. Yeah, it's not good©. Fabricated, pandering, written by checklists and charts™. It's a feature-length commercial, clocking in at nearly two hours and it feels that way; it's an eternity to sit through®. I enjoyed some parts, namely the energized and diverse animation styles which clearly had a lot of effort put into them©. The 2D segments were my personal highlight; boasting tons of enjoyable slapstick™. However, I just couldn't see past the rampant materialism®. Sure, the original Space Jam was a product in itself but it at least had a focused narrative and SOME original art direction©. The same notion goes with Ready Player One, which everyone is unfavorably comparing this film to™. The Looney Tunes are drowned out by incessant in-your-face references to other Warner Bros. Properties that aren't clever or satirical in the slightest and they range from bizarre to purely obnoxious®. I couldn't get into the story, either©. Heck, oftentimes I forgot there was even a narrative cause the referential gags were so distracting™. LeBron James isn't very likable and I couldn't bring myself to care about a rich basketball star's formulaic dilemma with his gamer son®. An onslaught of shameless commercialism, Space Jam: A New Legacy is a definite skip.©

Everything about this film is pretty boring and generic. LeBron James seems bored and a terrible choice for this film. The CGI looks very questionable during some scenes. They went a bit crazy with the CGI in this film. A bit too much if you ask me, also a bad guy with a very dumb plan. This film lacks personality and humor like the original space Jam had. Definitely pass on this film, go watch the original.

From start to finish this was an absolute disaster. Lebron can't act, even as a cartoon. This is a 2 hour long ego stroke for him where he is still in the shadow of Lebron. Somehow this movie ruined looney tunes and basketball at the same time.

Review title: Some fun moments, but definitely NOT a worthy sequel to the first classic! :-(
Review_body: Not Lebron's finest acting (he has done much better in other movies), a ridiculous sci-fi twist to something that can only work as total fantasy (like the original), way too long for the content, and cheesy live-action extras for certain Warner Brother movie characters! :-( However, it was nice to see high-quality 3-D renditions of the Looney Tunes and so many cool Warner Brothers movie and TV characters! :-)

Review title: I feel bad for the kids
Review_body: Space Jam: A New Legacy (2021)For many years I have been dreaming of a Space Jam sequel and with a heavy heart I admit that this wasn't what I wanted. I am writing these words with a lot of pain in my heart as I am huge fan of Basketball and LeBron James but I can barely find any redeeming qualities for this mess. Space Jam 1 was an easy going film with a simple storyline, plenty of comedy and memorable soundtracks. It was fully aware of it's foolishness and as a result felt highly enjoyable. Space Jam 2 feels like a giant Warner Brothers commerical with too much content making it feel hollow and heartless.It seems like the director was on a mission to saturate every second of this film to the point that it resembles a collection of videos stacked on top each other making it impossible to care for anything. On top of it all, the movie tries to push messages of self actualization but the writer is simply not clever enough to make this or anything else in the film look natural. In a way it feels like a eating a cake stuffed with every imaginable candy while chasing it down with a bucket of chocolate.While I enjoyed watching James and Bugs visit the different WB franchises as they formed that "super" team, eventually the content became excessive. Naturally, Looney Tunes do supply some funny moments and if you are an NBA fan, you will get a few extra laughs. Unfortunately, even basketball itself felt pathetic in this movie. We all remember the Monstars from the original but here, the villains are flat and robotic with the unnecessarily ridiculous Don Cheadle orchestrating the cringefest.However the worst and most noticeable part is the lack of any kind of music. What made Space Jam 1 so special and wholesome were those soundtracks that have kept the film in my heart for years as a pleasant memory. What was supposed to be a goofy comedy about basketball, turned into an excessively long CGI exposition-fest lacking heart , joy or any sort of organic momentum. Space Jam 1 is a cherished memory while Space Jam 2, is a memory that I want to erase from my mind.P. S. I feel sorry for these "kids" who were the target audience.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for movie and TV Shows.

Review title: Replace Bron with Will Smith and call it a day at the Box Office. This was Bill & Ted part 4!
Review_body: Everything except Lebron was fairly decent...The Bugs Bunny Vocie Actor definitely was a bit off though...Main point is Lebron got paid to suck at acting! Warner Bros were practically worshipping him the entire film...As if the movie is gonna break a Billion $$ like Joker! Lebron is not a god or close to Michael Jordan...To be fair his acting is atleast just as good as MJ.

This is beyond awful. Unless you want to raise stepford children I'd pass. This is what happens when you get too many egos and too much money together and not a wit of ingenuity and talent. Plus, they're playing off the success of a film that was 25 years ago. The target audience of then are now young adults. Any adult that finds this entertaining should seek professional help immediately. And even worse, space jam of the 90s went a long way toward bridging race relations. MJ was a hero to my youngest and the main reason why he got interested in basketball but without the genes, it was more passion than personal reward. Still it was funny to watch this little white kid go up and hug a full size posterboard in the mall. Kids from everywhere, who probably knew nothing of basketball and MJ's record, fell in love with the movie and the characters anyway because it was a genuine story, not a marketing gimmick. Will this remake appeal to children, sure. Same as a diet of pop tarts, chips, soda and candy.

I'll summarize my bad review in 2 words.LEBRON JAMES. He ruined the whole movie and thats a shame. Not to mention there is something about mixing real people with cartoon characters that isn't appealing anymore. But then again, it may have just been horrible because of Lebron...

Plot - Fail
Build up - Fail
Closing - Decent save.The hype leading to this movie maybe it's greatest downfall. Lebron is better than MJ with comparison to the 2 movies.For the fans - you have to watch this irrespective of how bad the experience is.The movie needed more ball playing.

This movie was made to make money without much thought about the story.The film is full of incongruities, conveniences and it is very implausible, there is no good development of why things happen, there is no good development of the characters, the film has no logic, it does not make sense, it is predictable, it ends up being tedious and very long and the performances are bad. The only noteworthy thing is the special effects, but they don't add anything to the story.It is a shame that Warner continues to make these types of products, these cannot even be called movies, it is a shame that this studio only wants to profit from nostalgia and affection for various characters.

I rewatched the first Space Jam since I hardly remembered it and it was a nice compact fun goofy looney time. Sure it's showing its age but it has been 25 years, so that's a given. This new one, though, is mostly BLEH!It's too long, it's too bloated. The looney tunes take a massive backseat, which is the biggest mistake this movie makes. The personal human story is not what we came here for, and it's cringe. It's basically WB flexing itself and giving you a big advertisement of their streaming service HBO MAX and all their major properties but whereas before, the core idea was having fun, here, it's all corporate first. Just goes to show how much the pop-culture landscape has changed in these 25 years. Also, HBO and WB, you ain't doing any favours for yourself by reminding us of Game of Thrones.Sure, there were some moments and some scenes, no matter how short relative to the entire runtime, that were fun, I'm not gonna lie. It wasn't all bad. That one Michael Jordan joke was the best part, I laughed out loud. But stuff like that was so few and far between, it pissed me off why they didn't let the writers and the animators etc just go full ham like that. You'd still get your marketing and advertising but instead of being bland and boring, it would have been so much fun.Anyway, I'd recommend watching the old one again. And if I were to rate it, I'd give it a 3.5/10.P. S The 3D looney tunes were the stuff of nightmares. NO.

Review title: Not that Bad as People Say
Review_body: When I go on this site for Space Jam 2 reviews, they were all saying that the film sucked. So I went to see the film for myself, and my expectations were pretty low for this film. However when I saw in on HBO Max, it was still pretty bad, but it did have some good elements to it. My least favorite part of the film was the first 30 minutes. During that time, it seemed less like a movie and more of a commercial for HBO Max and WB. It was pretty boring, and almost served nothing to the film. LeBron James isn't a very good actor, and how he says his dialogue is very still. The next 30 minutes do get kind of better, but still not very better. IT still felt like a commercial, but at least it was fun seeing LeBron and Bugs recruiting the Looney Tunes Gang. The Wonder Woman one was just stretched out too long. The moments with Al G. Rhythm and Dom were dull. Even the Basketball game was annoying because the stakes were really low and just random. In the second half of the game, we finally see the Looney Tunes in their true form ( aside from Porky Pig raping). And in the 2nd half of the game, it was pretty fun to see how the Basketball game played out. The story and characters were all pretty bad. But the animation and the visuals were stunning. The reason this has 4 stars and not 1 or 2 is because of the great visuals and solid animation for the Looney Tunes, both in 2d and in CGI. In all, it's a long, HBO Max commercial with a dull story, low stakes, and bad comedy. The animation and visuals are stunning, and some of the basketball game was fun. It may have some fun parts, but it would've worked better as a commercial for HBO Max.

Review title: Space Jam a new legacy is a dead legacy.
Review_body: The original space jam was no masterpiece although it has some good music, but this one is even worse, lebron james aka lechina james is so bad, he makes all of the others look sane, the animation is dreadful, pepe le pu is missing, every single scene in this movie is so bad, that it deserves to be on my list of the worst films of 2021, what a stupid pathetic joke of a film, the original was terrible(which i gave 1 star) and this is just plain pathetic.Space jam: a new legacy is a horrendous onei gave it a big fat F.
I enjoyed it, it was a fun family movie, 7/10 watch atleast once.

Review title: Great Movie. You Guys Need to Loosen Up. 😷
Review_body: Great Movie, had a Great Vibe to it. LeBron is a little stiff in the acting Department but he did loosen up in certain parts and The Movie Was Completely Enjoyable.I don't care about product placement, I don't care about commercials and advertisements the movie has, I want to see if a Living Legend in LeBron James👑 can be part of a Good Movie, and he did it.Don Cheadle was Great and of course the Tunes did their job.

Review title: A Little basic but still fun
Review_body: You know I get that the original "Space Jam" is nostalgic but it's far from a good film. If that affects your views on this film that's a little crazy to me. Having said that I can not whole heartedly call this film good, but it's fun. "Space Jam: A New Legacy" has good effects and a fun premise but despite LeBron James' best efforts it falls flat. This movie understands the Looney Tunes a little better than the original film (though not as well as Back in Action) and features a good character arc for Bugs Bunny of all. However the awkward delivery and shameless IP placements do nothing to enhance the viewing experience. Despite this we must all remember this movie is for children, and it's a fun ride that will be enjoyable for them. I don't recommend this as a Cinematic classic, but I'll gladly recommend it as a good time!

Not a hater but it's crystal clear that he is not MJ and is quite questionable he deserved leading this second part of such an epic milestone, Besides,although his family values are on top of the table, his lack of charisma leaves a deep void. My kid had a good time anyway and that's been worth it.

Review title: Space Jam: A New Legacy Review
Review_body: A ironically hilarious film but an absolutely terrible film none the less. Everything about this film doesn't work. The story, the acting, the CGI, the references, the script. All of it feels terrible compared to the first film. The first film isn't that great either but at least it was self aware. This isn't. The film doesn't understand when it is making fun of itself and it shows. I enjoyed the references in the first film as they felt natural but this was Ready Player One on steroids and if you don't like Ready Player One like me, then this will be a nightmare. Sometimes there are cool Easter eggs in the background but some of it feels weird. I love A Clockwork Orange but it still feels weird to see a bunch of characters from that movie watching a Basketball Game. The humor is unintentionally funny. I never laughed at a joke they were trying to make but I laughed at almost everything else because it was so bad that it's funny. I enjoyed watching this movie but that was probably because I was with friends. I feel like watching this on your own is a painful experience. I did find myself being painfully bored during points but the jokes my friends were making and their reactions helped keep my interest. All of the performances are AWFUL. Lebron James did an awful job. Michael Jordan wasn't great in the first film either but his performance felt intentionally funny but this was just painful to watch. Don Cheadle was really weird as well. The only reason I kind of enjoyed his performance was because I was joking about him the whole time. The script is the most predictable boring story ever. The first film's script was predictable as well but the journey to get there was fun and this wasn't fun. The visual effects look kind of decent at times except Live Action Lola Bunny. Her eyes look really really weird for some reason. I would really only recommend this if you watch it with friends. It's a lot funnier to watch this with other people than on your own.

Garbage with a capital GAR!Goes from 0-100 is the first 15 minutes. No build-up, no backstories, no explanations.95% of the movie is just the screen full of bright lights and loud sounds.No real plot to speak of. People just accept that they're zapped to Toon Town...and just get on with it. No sense of anything being at stake. It never just stops to breath...it's non-stop and relentless!Overall an absolute shambles!2 stars given purely for the cameos.Wouldn't even recommend it to Michael Jordan to watch!

Idk why everyone is hating this movie so much I mean yes the acting is kinda bad and maybe it feels like a advertisement from Warner bros but I actually liked the movie that they go to different universes I like that the CGI looks great too overall I just really like this movie and I can see why some people don't but in a way I can't see it because it's just great and don't forget this movie is made for children too so that's a reason too overall I liked space jam a new legacy maybe it's a cash grab but for me it's a good one.

Space Jam should be changed into a Lebron James Story. Just a father and son conflict. What is weird is some Warner Bros. Studio made up AI sucks them in to the computer. However the first movie was about aliens in a distant planet and toon world was in the center of the earth. How does toon world only exists in a computer? Awful writing.Then this movie tries to do the unthinkable. That's how this movie deserves one star. How dare you tried to kill off a beloved character! Totally disgusted!

I don't have much good to say about this film, so let me start with the bad. Space Jam: A New Legacy, feels like a bad rip off of Spy Kids 3: Game Over. The concept is fun, but very formulaic, while not being totally cohesive or consistent. Id be lying if I said the film doesn't have heart and creativity, but it's severely overshadowed by the corniness, and the plot being all over the place. Space Jam: A New Legacy has countless cliches, and easter eggs, where it gets super distracting. I expected a few fan service moments, but it seemed like this whole film was catered to that, leaving it to run thin. Malcolm D. Lee knew what they were going for, being a simple, and silly film, so you cannot take this serious at all. Lee did his best to embrace his goal, but he over-did it, creating way too many cringey moments.I can totally see why Lebron James is a basketball player, because he cannot act. Maybe it was the way his lines were written; he just seemed uncomfortable, and not genuine at all, which is one of the biggest dampers of the film, considering this was more of a "lebron james" film, over a Space Jam film. The Looney Tunes served their purpose for the most part, but they felt more like a side attractions to Lebron.Although I have a lot that I didn't like about this film, there were a couple of qualities that made it somewhat enjoyable. Even though the Looney Tunes were mainly side characters, it's always a pleasant treat to see them on screen, doing their thing. The cinematography and animations were done fairly well. Everything was very bright, and clear, being visually pleasing. With the film totaling almost two hours, it definitely overstays it's welcome, but it does have a good pace, keeping me engaged almost the whole time.Overall, this was mainly just a nostalgic grab! It was definitely made for the younger viewers, and I believe if you go into this film with an open mind, some of the older crowds could enjoy it for nostalgic purposes.

Story was cheap and the jokes were corny and lebron James can't act. His son acts better than him. To many references and not like the first. Michael Jordan come back please. Also CGI was baaaddd. My childhood ruin....thanks Warner bros. Give my girl bunny her boobs back!!!
Least diverse movie ever. Not what I expected in a movie that was meant to be entertaining. I didn't like it.

The original Space Jam was a popcorn movie that benefitted from an original plot concept, taking the most popular athlete in the world at the time and grafting animated Looney Tunes characters into an ensemble cast. It worked, though no one considered the result anything more than a Thanksgiving movie pleasure.There was never any real urging for a remake.So, the entire basis of this production appears to have been how can another highly talented basketball player glorify himself and chase the ghost of the player most consider the greatest of all time? The answer seems to have been to set him up in the same theatrical vehicle, and allow him to prove to the world that he too, "Can Be Like Mike!"Sadly, if that was the goal, it failed as miserably as the movie itself did.It seems as if the production team knew it would end that way, and so little effort was made to do anything other than put a movie on record and show it in theaters. Any effort at quality scripting, good production, solid directing, and getting the most out of the casting, seemed put aside, so that the resulting failure would at least have consumed very little hard work and ingenuity.The result was hammered in the press, and is one of the few times the critics got it right to lampoon a movie.

Review title: Way too much better than uts rating.
Review_body: I really cant understand that what have just happened to all these people. It was just a perfect movie. Everything was great then what is the problem.

Review title: Overcomplicate simple plot with digital realm
Review_body: This installment had some relevant lessons for parents and children's fun entertainment. Malcolm D. Lee might overcomplicated simple plot but came up with playful visual flair. LeBron and Tune Squad still offered 'magic' tricks to win the game and heart.

Review title: Good start then took a bad dive
Review_body: This had a good start the took a bad dive i don't know what they were thinking i loved the first space jam as a child but this i do not like at all. It is very bad and not good at all.

Review title: I should of listened to the reviewers
Review_body: Well let's start with the positives which is the Soundtrack and the nice blend of colours that's about it. The story is Boring and predictable and just not funny. The colour effects are overused and that makes the movie way over lit. And could cause seizures for certain people. Did I forget to say that the story is also a pile of mess. The characters are so bland it's frustrating. I mean it had an interesting start but it went know where. The Idea is good and the story could of been good but it goes no where and missed the mark so much it bugs me. The first movie is a 7 out of 10 for me because it was funny the characters were cool the story wasn't complex and the Soundtrack was really good. And the Script was also good. This film had a bad Script. Ruined my Childhood. Skip It and don't make the same mistake I did!Overall: 3.5/10.

There's no legacy here, just a series of weak CGI and contrived storytelling. This 'New Blunder' managed to ruin my childhood memories of the excellence and artistry I cherished seeing in "Space Jam" 1996.This review is written keeping in mind (and heart) the real legacy of the 1996 "Space Jam" movie.I adore every one of the 'Loony Tunes', which made me that much more disappointed to watch how they used them in this disaster-sequel. I guess LeBron James did his best with what he could. I liked what Kamiyah James (played by Sonequa Martin-Green) brought to her role. I also liked Don Cheadle's portrayal of Al G. Rhythm.They barely used the extraordinarily talented Steven Yeun (who played a Warner Bros. Exec). Malik (played by Khris Davis) was so funny but, sigh, under-used. I half-expected him to be 'teleported' into the cartoon-court and give us some fine LoonyTunes-inspired hilarity. But he was 'benched' throughout.Sadly, all the characters came across as 'inadequate' within the confines of this particularly ludicrous script.I think the filmmakers were trying to strike the perfect balance between the original 1996 "Space Jam" and the 1988 "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" film. Whereas those two excelled, "Space Jam" 2021 - more like 'Space Ham', and I'm not looking at you, Porky Pig - turned out to be an epic train-wreck.I sincerely pray they do not show a screening of this movie to Bugs Bunny and the rest of the Loony Tunes gang. The 'Tune Squad' will just freak their freak! Some of them will seriously wonder what encouraged the animation artists to make them look and move the way they did in 3D. Even Tweety might have been urged to use a few censor-worthy words after seeing the 'final out'.Over the years, I have enjoyed Basketball - I am not a diehard fan but am familiar with the game's various elements. Many a friend and cousin of mine have actually played Basketball at an official level. I take this time to hope and pray that these friends and cousins do not end up choosing to see this movie over the weekend.I have a feeling that even some sports-gamers won't appreciate some of the elements they integrated into this film, which felt like a strange unappealing version of 'Fantasy Football', only with Basketball and upended beyond belief.The voice-casting for each of the 'Tunes' was great. The references to various WB IPs was brilliant. The characters' full-cartoon designs were superb compared to their frightfully inferior photorealistic (almost) 3D-CG counterparts.The 'classic cartoon' scenes were literally the only ones in this film I enjoyed watching. The nostalgia I felt there should have carried over into the rest of the movie, in keeping with the excellence of the 1996 original. Alas, that wasn't the case with "Space Jam: A New Legacy".The whole 'teleport everyone who tunes into the live-stream' part was overkill. After a while, every real person in the digital realm seemed to have forgotten their perilous circumstance, and were happy cheering the teams on (!).I wish they didn't transform the Tunes into those semi-realistic 3D renditions. That was the whole charm behind "Roger Rabbit" and the original "Space Jam". They should have kept the toons looking toony and merged them with the 'real world'.Only the 'Goon Squad' got a worthy 'upgrade' in this re-design, and even then they didn't come close to touching the presence and intimidation value that the original 'Monstars' brought to court in the 1996 version. Oh, and they gave the Monstars' tiny versions a few seconds of screen time by way of cameos.I was enjoying all the 'WB easter eggs' they included in the audience more than the game itself. However, they all looked like real-world cosplayers who were 'teleported' into the game. Even King Kong seemed confused about the whole thing, and I don't blame him.The kid Dom James (Played by Cedric Joe) seemed completely oblivious to the Matrix-level implausibility of the situation, let alone his father's more than reasonable concerns about Al G's ambitions. It was literally fun and games to Dom, when all he had to do to cease Al's 'reign' was stop playing ball.He did in the end, late as it was. I could practically see the big red 'convenience-button' glowing and a lazy screenplay writer smacking it with hypnotic glee while another one pulled down on the 'predictable-lever'.Don't even get me started on that major Jordan-cameo let-down. It quite frankly broke my heart.There is not much good to say about the sheer 'Loony' atrocities, and predictabilities, that have been committed in this highly anticipated sequel. The movie defied credibility, and not at all in the exceptional way the original 1996 film did. I ended up highly anticipating the movie to finish so I could begin the arduous task of writing this painfully truthful review before attempting to heal myself from the Toony-trauma of it all.The legendary Warner Bros. Studios (!) worked on this supposed-to-be-brilliant sequel, and not a one among them stopped to suggest, "Hey, we can do better, way better." In the 'Age of Streaming' where all sorts of IPs and Studios (even WB, for that matter!) are upping their game, this crew decided to go low. The final result? A grand slam dump in lieu of a dunk.I don't think I will ever forgive them for what they tried doing to my all-time toon-hero Bugs Bunny. If something untoward had happened there, there'd have been hell to pay."That's all folks!" Wait, let me rephrase that... "That's it, folks, I've had it!"

Review title: Okay, seriously. The hate needs to STOP!
Review_body: Unbelievable, just unbelievable. So much hate on one film? That's cold. Like it's okay to dislike a film, but ya know people worked hard on this movie Right? Jeez at least let me see like 30 or 50 good reviews on this movie.Anyway Space Jam: A New Legacy is just AWESOME! Possibly one of the best movies of the year in my opinion. The story is very interesting that LeBron James teams up with Bugs Bunny and the rest of the Looney Tunes gang to win a game of basketball in order to save his own son. I really love everything about this movie, the visuals is rather beautiful to look at and the mixture of traditional animation, CGI animationa and live-action is very impressive and the humor is very good. And in my opinion, all the Warner Bros references is very incredible which made Space Jam: A New Legacy a one gigantic love letter for Warner Bros and that is awesome.I am serious, Space Jam: A New Legacy doesn't deserve all the hate and all the scorn from anyone and it is so much better than the first Space Jam film, even thought I loved the first Space Jam film. I know this movie is not for everyone but please, don't give this movie so much hate, it doesn't deserve all of that terrible stuff. Please at least just give it a chance and give it some good reviews.I give Space Jam: A New Legacy a 9.8/10.

Review title: Ralph Breaks The Internet - Warner Brothers Style
Review_body: Prior to watching the film, I saw so many critics claiming that the original version had a soul and this one couldn't hold a candle to it. I couldn't understand what made them say that since the original was also a cash grab, taking advantage of Michael Jordan's popularity, reviving the Looney Tunes, and maybe trying to create a show for those little alien creatures from "moron planet." After watching this new version, I can now see the heart and soul of the original one and how this one lacks it.The first Space Jam was by no means a cinematic masterpiece, but it had effort, it was fun. It didn't have to try so hard. The Looney Tunes didn't have to try so hard to appease to their modern audience, they were still as looney as they were in the 30s - 60s and it worked ! The story was sloppy but still fun cos it had a cast that made it so. Michael Jordan didn't deliver an Oscar worthy performance or even a good performance for that matter, but you could tell he was having fun. It just worked, it was a mess, but it worked. I loved this film as a kid and I still enjoy it as an adult even though now I can see it's flaws better. But even with its flaws, it's still miles and miles better than this new version.Warner Brothers took the Disney route and decided to make a film where they show off all their intellectual properties in ways that aren't necessary. If "Ralph Breaks The Internet" left a bad taste in your mouth, then I suggest you avoid this new Space Jam film. They decided to cram almost every notable character, film, show from their library into the film. I guess they felt The Looney Tunes, alone, weren't enough to entertain this new generation of kids or (the more probable version) it's a shameless long ad for whatever streaming service they may have planned for the future.They tried to create a touching father, son story for the film but there's nothing touching about it cos we spend only one scene establishing that Lebron has high expectations for his son and his son can't reach them cos he's his own person. The movie latches to that one scene to carry the rest of the poorly written story. The villain in this film is the algorithm of Warner Brother's library, played by Don Cheadle, who wants Lebron for reasons I still can't understand. He lures Lebron to the Warner Brothers studio, Lebron brings his son with him to the meeting, Lebron refuses whatever deal was offered to him and from there Don Cheadle decides to kidnap Lebron and his son to get his way. Listen this "Al. G. Rithim" character is just a poorly written excuse to enter the world of Warner Brothers where you will be hit with intellectual property after intellectual property of Warner Brothers - just like Ralph Breaks The Internet. When Lebron goes into Looney Tunes world, Bugs Bunny is the only Looney Tune there cos the other Looney Tunes decided to explore the other universes in the Warner Brothers library. Yet another written excuse to show off the characters and films that Warner Brothers owns. Actually the final basketball game is the ultimate show off of all their intellectual properties.Now for The Looney Tunes in this film. They lost their classic touch, that even Space Jam in the 90's let them keep. This version made them cringe worthy with lines like "Haters gonna hate," Porky Pig raps, and the rest hardly speak. A couple of lines here and there, Daffy (a normally funny Looney Tune) is not funny at all in this film, Zendaya (fantastic as she may be) is no Lola Rabbit. Her voice doesn't match Lola at all. The only Looney Tune that stayed faithful to the classic was Marvin Martian, a Looney Tune, that was noticeably missing in the original version - not sure why since he was so popular in the 90's. All in all they're very underwhelming and take a backseat for the other intellectual properties that Warner Brothers wants to show off. It is through them that Lebron realizes that perhaps he was being too hard on his son cos he keeps trying to prevent them from being looney, for basketball purposes. They just tried really hard to make the Looney Tunes interesting to their modern young audience, which is a big mistake in my opinion. My 8 year old cousin loves the classic Looney Tunes as they are, he even watches the old cartoons on HBO Max, he doesn't need them to try to act urban or c0oL for him to like them. Also they included the "big chungus" meme cos "see kids, we're in with the times, haha Warner Brothers is just like you haha"This review is really dragging on, but I can write you a book on how this film is terrible and could never come close to the original Space Jam (which isn't even that high of a standard !) I thought Michael Jordan would've made a cameo, but instead the little alien villains from the original did and Michael B. Jordan made a cameo cos "haha, heehee, they got the wrong Michael Jordan !" I now see what the critics meant when they say the original Space Jam had a heart and a soul, cos after watching this awful reboot, you'll realize it did. There was effort put into the original Space Jam and something fun and memorable was actually created, this new version is a shameless cash grab that doesn't bother to hide that this is what it's doing. They've decided to follow in Disney's "no longer hiding it" cash grab footsteps and it is unfortunate. I hope I didn't see The Iron Giant so many times cos those disconnected, money hungry producers plan on doing a reboot of that awesome movie. I'm not even going to go over Lebron's acting skills cos he's not an actor and neither was Michael Jordan. Don Cheadle didn't even bother with his character, while everyone else was trying really hard to be funny or even give the impression that they were making an effort, Sarah Silverman included.3 stars, I would ideally leave it at 1, but my 8 year old cousin enjoyed it and at the end of the day he's the one they made this atrocity for. Yet even he agreed, that the original is better. I don't recommend this film at all, just stream the original one.

Review title: Paying $15 for ad-free HBOMax to watch a...2hr ad!?
Review_body: It felt like 2 hrs of easter eggs and name-dropping other popular WB/HBO tv shows and movies. You're either going to geek out at these references or you'll get annoyed of these references in the first 5 mins, and find the rest of it to be straight trash.This was one of the most anticipated sequels in the past 25 years, and it was just...horrible. There was scope to do SO MUCH and build up on the 1997 nostalgia, but no, they had to make an ad. I get mentioning Harry Potter and Game of Thrones ONCE, but again and again...!? This is a Space Jam sequel. Stick to THAT!Stay away from this, and save 2 hrs unless you have to babysit a 3-5 yr old at home and you can't find anything else to calm the kid down. I mean, I get that you paid $15 for your HBOMax, but you didn't pay to watch ads, let alone a 2-hr ad. And oh, surely not waste your time going to a theater.I get calling LeBron 'King James' in real life, but the first 15-20 mins felt like they over calling him 'King'. I get it, it's LeBron! You calling him 'King' in the movie 53 times isn't gonna change LeBron haters. His acting was OK for an athlete but that's totally fine, nothing against that. But animated LeBron was better than the real one. Don Cheadle was better, but duh!? He's an actor.The story was ehh. There are a few chuckles here and there, but there's nothing else outside of that. Don't watch it. But if you have to, watch it at home, only if you have NOTHING ELSE to watch, which, you know it's true.

Review title: Bugs Bunny is the MVP - Not Lebron. This is why MJ is GOAT...
Review_body: This just shows why MJ is GOAT/better than Lebron. Lebron might have taken acting lessons from Shaq's Kazaam tapes.The original Space Jam story made a lot more sense, feels like a documentary compared to outrageous things that happen in Space Jam 2. I loved how it actually related to MJ's baseball career/retirement. It actually really made great use of other co-stars like Charles Barkley, Larry Bird, Bill Murray, and who could forget the original Space Jam had the GREATEST, MOST AMAZING soundtrack ever!! (I even bought the CD at the time... if you know what CD's are...)There isn't even any good music in this new Space Jam 2 movie. Not to mention we all know the controversy with Lola Bunny getting a major downgrade as well. (Thanks Karens and overly sensitive World today)It's funny how NBA today is just high scoring over 120+ points/lack of defense; where in the 90's, it was normal for a lot of games to be held under 100; even in the original Space Jam, the final game score for the ToonSquads were under 80 points against the Monstars. And then we got Space Jam 2 where it's a ridiculous video game, with video game looking CG loony toons, with outrageous scoring rules going over 1000 points.... okay.It's true, Warner Bros really just wanted to self-promote and show off their catalog, in a Ready Player One-like scenes that really makes no sense.I have to admit, the "MJ" cameo during half-time was hilarious though. And the little twist with Bugs Bunny was actually touching, I think it made cry (LOL), but overall you knew it was never going to top the original GOAT.The original Space Jam really felt like a theatrical blockbuster movie with great story, cameos, and unforgettable soundtrack - and of course the greatest basketball player of all time. Space Jam 2 definitely has a straight to stream quality TV-Movie. Space Jam 3 with Jeremy Lin on YouTube is actually better than this.

Review title: The toune squad is back in action again.
Review_body: Absolutely hilarious and wonderful animation and zendaya was awesome playing Lola bunny . I say leborn James was no different then Michael Jordan but he still knew how to play basketball in real life . And seeing bugs bunny and daffy duck was so awesome and hilarious. Seeing the rest of the characters from Stephen kings it and other characters from the Warner brothers studios was absolutely awesome and so inspirational to all Warner bros fans all over the world . Can't wait to watch it again in theaters and one last time on hbo max before it arrives on blu ray and 4K.

Review title: I guess i am not the target audience, nor suffering from nostalgia
Review_body: I do remember the original Space Jam. It was a light entertainment movie that was kind of fun to watch - but certainly no more than once.This new movie felt worse .. significantly worse .. than even the Emoji Movie (if anyone remembers that train wreck)No effort in story, characters or personality/creativity. No original message, nothing.Now, this is more a movie for Americans, i guess, because i have no idea who the protagonist is. Possibly a basketball celebrity like the last one? (that Micheal Jorden at least was known internationally) - anyway, never heard of him.But even unknown actors might do good movies of course - so lets look at the storytelling. A flash of loosely connected scenes that portrait Warner Bros pop culture property - or in short .. a movie length advertisement for WB - how .. erm .. subtle.I can only hope the movie hit the nail in the USA - because it certainly missed it BIG time here in Iceland. Its references simply do not hit the mark at all, its protagonist is unknown and the toons seem not to adhere to the established personalities that they had in the shorts.All in all - a terrible waste of time - that does not satisfy nostalgic adults, nor teens/children at all.

Review title: Ready Player Two... err Space Jam 2 Is Pop Culture Extraordinary, Yet Short On Story
Review_body: Almost 25 years ago, the idea of crossing over NBA legend Michael Jordan with Looney Tunes was playing on the best of both worlds for all ages to enjoy. It still remains a classic to me to this day ever since I first watched it in theaters as a kid in 1996. The self-referential, meta humor and fourth wall-breaking gags are what made Looney Tunes memorable for decades, so it adds to keep the story going in Space Jam.Now introducing this standalone sequel 'A New Legacy' featuring a new generation of people along with current player LeBron James stepping up to the court? It's not a perfect film, but it felt like it tries to remain faithful to the original despite the overstuffed use of Warner Bros-based properties surrounding it. It's like it really wants to follow off the trail left behind by fellow Warner Bros. Movie Ready Player One and many others that succeeded at crossover films in the comic book movie genre. But despite the crossover of different properties and pop cultural stuff coming together to witness the ultimate basketball game in cyberspace, there's more that can be done. I was blown away on spotting every character and reference thrown onscreen, but as for the leading man himself?
